A tungsten dragon prefers to make its home in deserts and arid plains. They enjoy basking in the heat of the sun at its peak, and bathing themselves in boiling hot sand when possible. This ritual keeps their scales smooth and removes any imperfections that might hinder them as they burrow through the ground. Their actual lairs are usually in rocky caves, though when no such locale is available they will settle for making a home deep underground.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The dragon can use its Frightful Presence. It then makes three attacks: one with its bite and two with its claws.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 17} to hit, reach 15 ft., one creature.
{@h}21 ({@damage 2d10 + 10}) piercing damage.

action.name: Claw
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 17} to hit, reach 10 ft., one creature.
{@h}21 ({@damage 2d10 + 10}) slashing damage.

action.name: Tail
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 17} to hit, reach 20 ft., one target.
{@h}19 ({@damage 2d8 + 10}) bludgeoning damage.

action.name: Frightful Presence
entries: Each creature of the dragon's choice that is within 120 feet of the dragon and aware of it must succeed on a {@dc 21} Wisdom saving throw or become {@condition frightened} for 1 minute. A creature can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success. If a creature's saving throw is successful or the effect ends for it, the creature is immune to the dragon's Frightful Presence for the next 24 hours.

action.name: Breath Weapon {@recharge 5}
entries: The dragon exhales a blast of superheated molten sand  in a 90-foot cone. Each creature in that area must make a {@dc 24} Constitution saving throw, taking 36 ({@damage 8d8}) bludgeoning damage and 36 ({@damage 8d8}) fire damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

action.name: Immolation (1/Day)
entries: All creatures  within 60 feet of the dragon burst into flames, taking 66 ({@damage 12d10}) fire damage, or half as much on a successful {@dc 24} Dexterity Saving Throw. On a failed save the target also catches fire, taking 11 ({@damage 2d10}) fire damage at the start of each of their turns until someone takes an action to douse the fire.

action.name: Sand Cloud (1/Day)
entries: The dragon exhales a cloud of fine sand in a 60-foot radius centred on itself. The cloud of sand snuffs out all non-magical flames in the area and any creature that is {@status concentration||concentrating} on a spell that starts its turn within the sand cloud must succeed on a {@dc 15} Concentration Check or lose {@status concentration}. The area within the cloud is heavily obscured. The cloud lasts for 1 hour before the sand settles to the ground.

trait.name: Legendary Resistance (3/Day)
entries: If the dragon fails a saving throw, it can choose to succeed instead.

legendary.name: Detect
entries: The dragon makes a Wisdom (Perception) check.

legendary.name: Tail Attack
entries: The dragon makes a tail attack.

legendary.name: Wing Attack (Costs 2 Actions)
entries: The dragon beats its wings. Each creature within 10 feet of the dragon must succeed on a {@dc 21} Dexterity saving throw or take 15 ({@damage 2d6 + 8}) bludgeoning damage and be knocked {@condition prone}. The dragon can then fly up to half its flying speed.

In its true form the pie fiend is a burly devil with massive bat-wings, cloven hooves, a pair of horns, and razor sharp teeth. They are often dressed in a thick leather apron which serves to protect their large belly. Unlike other devils, they smell not of smoke and brimstone, but of cinnamon and pastry.

Grudging Respect. Pie fiends are one of the strangest creatures to ever emerge from the hells, so strange in fact that some scholars believe them to be mere myth, nothing more than a joke exchanged between the learned. In reality, they are all too real, and it would behoove those who value their souls to take them seriously. Even other devils understand the power held by an accomplished pie fiend, and while they may make jokes about them in private, they are compelled to show these devils respect, lest they face the wrath of their superior.

Bakery of Souls. Like all devils who operate within The Nine Hells, pie fiends trade and barter in souls. They are highly intelligent, and master manipulators. Using their ability to take on the form of humanoid creatures to influence mortals seems to be their primary method of harvesting souls, afterall, one is much more likely to let their guard down around the kindly old woman who bakes delicious pies than they are around a bonafide devil from beyond the Material Plane. They often set up bakeries in small towns and then use their standing with the townsfolk to sway events one way or another in their favor. Occasionally they will even establish themselves in large cities, working in conjunction with other devils to bring the populace to its knees through the art of baking cursed confections. It is said that pie fiends are capable of baking sweets so incredible that a mortal might be tempted to trade their soul simply to have a second bite, and even if they don't get a soul out of the deal, it can at least provide the pie fiend with an unparalleled distraction.

Sweet Tooth. Unsurprisingly, pie fiends have a sweet tooth that would make even the most decadent noble blush. They love sweets, especially baked goods, and often go out of their way to acquire such things whenever the opportunity arises. They are exceptionally fond of baked treats that are made with unfamiliar methods, such as those from cultures not encountered by the fiend or a particular baker's specialty. They not only savor the flavor of these confections, but they also make sure to either find or figure out the recipe of any delectable dessert they come across in their recipe book. Every pie fiend's prize possession is their infernal tome of desert recipes. Each one contains all the desserts, both magical and mundane, that particular pie fiend knows how to make. The possibility of adding to this recipe book is often a driving force in any given pie fiend's actions.

trait.name: Magic Weapons
entries: The pie fiend's weapon attacks are magical.

action.name: Multiattack.
entries: The pie fiend makes three attacks with its club, or two attacks with its club and one atack with a thrown pie.

action.name: Club
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 13} to hit, reach 5 ft., one creature.
{@h}13 ({@damage 2d4 + 8}) bludgeoning damage.

action.name: Throw Pie
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 13} to hit, range 120/200 ft., one creature.
{@h}2 ({@damage 1d4 + 8}) bludgeoning damage plus any other damage or effects dealt by the pie.

action.name: Alter Self
entries: The pie fiend takes on a new physical appearance, or reverts back to its true form. The fiend decides what it looks like, including its height, weight, facial features, sound of its voice, hair length, coloration, and distinguishing characteristics, if any. It can make itself appear as a member of another race, and it can change its size to small, medium, or back to large. Its game statistics remain the same.

action.name: Animate Baked Goods {@recharge 5}
entries: The pie fiend bellows a word of command, permanently transforming {@dice 1d4} baked goods within 60 feet into {@creature pastrimp|dungeondadstatblocks}s. The pie fiend can have up to 13 pastrimps under its command at one time.

action.name: Heatwall {@recharge 5}
entries: Beginning from a point the pie fiend can see, it creates a wall of intense heat that is up to 60 feet long, 20 feet high, and 1 foot thick, or a ringed wall that is 20 feet in diameter, 20 feet high, and 1 foot thick. The wall is transparent and appears as heat waves rippling off the surface it is placed on. When the wall appears, each creature within its area must make a {@dc 18} Dexterity saving throw. On a failed save, a creature takes 22 ({@damage 5d8}) fire damage, or half as much damage on a successful save.  One side of the wall, chosen by the fiend, deals {@damage 5d8} fire damage to each creature that ends its turn within 10 feet of that side, or inside the wall. The wall lasts for 1 minute, or until the pie fiend uses this ability again.

action.name: Make Into Pie (3/Day)
entries: The pie fiend magically produces a sheet of flaky, thin, crust that it hurls at a huge or smaller target it can see within 100 feet. The target must make a {@dc 18} Dexterity Saving Throw or be {@condition restrained} by the dough (escape {@dc 18}). The dough has an AC of 16, resistance to piercing damage, immunity to bludgeoning damage, and 30 hit points. If the entangled creature takes fire damage from any source, that source deals the maximum amount of damage possible.

action.name: Waves of Contentment (1/Day)
entries: The pie fiend conjures an alluring scent that smells of freshly baked pies and pastries. All creatures within 60 feet of the fiend who can smell this scent must make a {@dc 18} Wisdom Saving Throw. A creature who fails this save is {@condition charmed} by the pie fiend and feels utterly content for the next 10 minutes. During this time, the creature can take no actions. The creature can attempt a {@dc 18} Wisdom Saving Throw at the end of each of their turns to end the effect early. Any amount of damage received by a {@condition charmed} creature ends the effect on them immediately.

bonus.name: Create Pie
entries: The pie fiend conjures a pie in the palm of its hand. If the pie has any special properties, they fade after 1 hour and the pie becomes mundane. It may choose to conjure any of the following types of pie;

-Mundane Pie: This pie and all of its ingredients are mundane, however, the fiend may choose what variety of filling is inside the pie such as fruit, meat, or custard. It has no special qualities, and is completely edible.

-Cold Pie: This pie contains frozen ice conjured from the stygian depths of the fifth layer of hell. Any creature hit with this pie takes 7 ({@damage 2d6}) cold damage. The remains of the pie cling to the target causing them to take 3 ({@damage 1d6}) cold damage at the start of their turn for the next minute, or until a creature uses an action to wipe away the remains.
-Hot Pie: Same as cold pie, but replace all instances of cold damage with fire damage.

-Sinfully Delicious Pie: This pie is a true masterpiece of the confectionary arts. Any living creature who so much as tastes this pie is driven into a fit of ecstasy and must make a {@dc 20} Wisdom Saving Throw. A creature who fails this save is {@condition stunned} for 1 minute. The pie fiend can only create one of these pies each day.

-Sticky Pie: This meringue-like confection is unbelievably sticky. A creature hit by this pie is {@condition restrained} (escape {@dc 18}) for 1 minute, or until the sticky pie debris is cleared away with acid.

This tiny creature appears, at first, to be nothing more than a delicious baked good. Closer inspection reveals that something is not quite right. While its body may resemble anything from a croissant to an expertly baked pie, this infernal little being is actually a devil in disguise.

Baker's Dozen. Pasrimps are confections infused with the soul of a mortal and brought to life as freshly baked devils. They serve at the behest of the pie fiend that created them, aiding in their master's schemes. If their creator is ever destroyed, the pastrimp may become a rogue fiend, following their whims and sowing chaos in their wake.

Bite Me. While they certainly pose a threat when fighting alongside their brethren, or a powerful pie fiend, the hidden danger of the pastrim lies within. The fiendish essence inherent in each pastrimp is a lethal toxin to any mortal creature who consumes it. Even a single bite can be enough to send a creature reeling. Normally this wouldn't be much of a problem, but due to the pastrimp's propensity for masquerading as a mundane dessert, many creatures have been the unsuspecting victim of this dastardly trait. Even worse is that the pastrim can use their alluring magic to entice the weak willed into taking a bit of them, even after they've revealed their true form.

trait.name: False Appearance
entries: While the pastrimp remains motionless, it is indistinguishable from a normal pie or pastry.

trait.name: Infernal Filling
entries: The body of a pastrimp is highly toxic to living creatures who are not devils. Any creature who hits a pastrimp with a bite attack, or eats any part of its body, takes 14 ({@damage 4d6}) poison damage, or half as much on a successful {@dc 14} Constitution Saving Throw. A creature who fails their save is also {@condition poisoned} for 1 minute. This damage does not break the effect of the pastrimp's intoxicating scent.

action.name: Stab
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 5} to hit, reach 5 ft., one creature.
{@h}10 ({@damage 2d6 + 3}) piercing damage.

action.name: Intoxicating Scent {@recharge 5}
entries: The pastrimp emits a powerful scent reminiscent of freshly baked desserts and cinnamon in a 30-foot cone. All living creatures in the area who are capable of consuming food must make a {@dc 14} Wisdom Saving Throw. Creatures who fail this save are {@condition charmed} by the pastrimp for 1 minute, or until they take damage from any source. While {@condition charmed} in this way, they gain a fly speed equal to half their walking speed and must use all their movement each turn to move closer to the pastrimp if possible. If they move within 5 feet of the pastrimp, or begin their turn there, they are compelled to make a bite attack against the pastrimp with their action. If the creature does not normally have a bite attack, they make an unarmed strike against the pastrimp using their mouth that deals {@damage 1d4} piercing damage. This attack always hits.

The figure standing before you emanates an aura of disquieting calm. While she cuts the silhouette of a beautiful humanoid creature, it's impossible to see any surface area of her physical body due to the shroud of pure white cloth that flows to-and-fro as if caught in an omnidirectional breeze. As the woman hovers into the air, she speaks with a voice, quiet as a whisper, but with the authority to move mountains.

Mother of Demons. Pale Night very well might be the oldest creature currently living within The Abyss, and possibly even the multiverse itself. There is much conflicting information about this enigmatic demoness, though one thing is certain, she is feared by all, even other demons. Pale Night is an Obyrith, a species of demon that is all but extinct. During their time in power, an age long before the first mortal drew breath, the Obryiths were the uncontested masters of The Abyss. As their ambition grew, eventually, they were hunted relentlessly by the Eladrin and other celestials intent on purging their dark influence from the multiverse. Despite this, Pale Night survived. She chose to bide her time, lurking in unseen places, methodically plotting her next move. Many believe it was Pale Night that gave rise to the first among the current population of demons living within The Abyss. She is said to be the mother of Graz'zt, among several other demon lords.

Veiled Madness. Pale Night's true form is something so horrific, so unbelievably wrong, that reality itself simply rejects her appearance. The veil that covers her entire body is a magical and cosmic effect put in place by the laws of the multiverse in order to prevent her from spilling out and corrupting everything around her. She is able to temporarily suppress this veil, however, it takes a tremendous amount of willpower meaning it is only possible to do so for mere moments. Some scholars believe the veil itself is some kind of divine being that came to be as a response to Pale Night's presence, however, this is still a subject of much debate. Most creatures who lay eyes upon her true form die instantly, and those who survive find it impossible to describe what they've seen. In many cases their memory simply lapses due to the fact that their brain is incapable of rationalising whatever it is that lies beyond the veil, and those who do retain even minor, inconsequential bits of information are typically rendered completely mad.

Winds of Change. The way Pale Night might react to an intruder within her realm is nearly impossible to predict. She is capricious and prone to flights of fancy that don't seem to follow any observable pattern. Sometimes she considers the mere act of a mortal speaking to her to be a sin worth of painful destruction. Other times, she seems completely aloof, and rarely, she even enjoys conversation with others, sending them on errands that typically involve the death of an enemy or rival demon in The Abyss. Whether this is just her chaotic nature as a demon lord made manifest, or the result of some unknown insight Pale Night possesses, it makes her a volatile entity to interact with.

Silent Cults. Like all demon lords, Pale Night has cultists on the Material Plane that worship her as a god. Unlike most other demon lords, she doesn't seek out or even interact with any of her cultists with almost no exception. Cults of Pale Night are typically focused on gaining access to her domain so that they might present themselves as humble servants to act in her service. Many cultists fantasise about being wrapped in her shroud and transformed into a shrouded knight in their lady's service.
Madness of Pale Night

If a creature goes mad in Pale Night's lair or within line of sight of the demon lord, roll on the Madness of Pale Night table to determine the nature of the madness, which is a character flaw that lasts until cured. See the Dungeon Master's Guide for more on madness.

entries.caption: Madness of Pale Night
rows: "Mortals are worthless in the grand scheme of the cosmos!"
"I must hide myself from the world. Don't look at me!"
"My mood swings like the pendulum on a grandfather clock."
"My skeleton is practically screaming to get out of my body. I don't know how long I can keep it from escaping."
"I must look beyond the veil, I must know what secret the demon mother keeps!"

trait.name: Chao Incarnate
entries: Any creature who attempts to read Pale Night's thoughts must succeed on a {@dc 30} Charisma Saving Throw or suffer the effects of the {@spell confusion} spell indefinitely. The creature can attempt another saving throw each day at dawn.

trait.name: Etheral Sight
entries: Pale Night can see 60 feet into the Ethereal Plane when it is on the Material Plane, and vice versa.

trait.name: Incorporeal Movement
entries: Pale Night can move through other creatures and objects as if they were difficult terrain. She takes 5 ({@damage 1d10}) force damage if she ends her turn inside an object.

trait.name: Legendary Resistance (3/Day)
entries: If the pale night fails a saving throw, it can choose to succeed instead.

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: The pale night has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

trait.name: Truth Beyond the Veil
entries: Pale Night's true form is one of such unimaginable horror that reality itself refuses to accept it. Her shroud is a magical effect that keeps her true form concealed at all times. It can't be destroyed by anything short of a wish spell, and even then, it is automatically restored after 1 hour. If a creature attempts to look beneath the shroud, the shroud moves, as if by some intelligence, to prevent anyone from seeing what lies beneath. If the shroud is forcibly removed or pulled aside, any creature within 30 feet who looks at Pale Night's true form must succeed on a {@dc 30} Charisma Saving Throw or instantly die. A creature who succeeds on this saving throw, or who dies and is revived, has no recollection of what they saw, but is left with an unshakable feeling of looming dread that follows them for the rest of their life.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: Pale Night makes two incorporeal touch attacks.

action.name: Incorporeal Touch
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 18} to hit, reach 5 ft., one creature.

{@h}32 ({@damage 4d10 + 10}) necrotic damage. If the target is a creature, it must succeed on a {@dc 24} Constitution saving throw or its hit point maximum is reduced by an amount equal to the damage taken. This reduction lasts until the target finishes a long rest. The target dies if its hit point maximum is reduced to 0.

action.name: Embrace (3/Day)
entries: Pale Night embraces a creature in her shroud. If the target is large or smaller, they must make a {@dc 26} Constitution Saving Throw or become {@condition stunned} until the end of their next turn. If the creature fails their save by 5 or more they are {@condition petrified}. While {@condition petrified} in this way the creature is still aware of its surroundings and it is not turned to stone, instead, their physical body becomes incorporeal and details of their form are obscured by a billowing shroud. If the creature is cured of its petrification it is able to behave normally, however, its body is still incorporeal and wrapped in a magical shroud.

action.name: Revelation of Truth (1/Day)
entries: Pale night suppresses her veil, revealing her true form. All creatures within 30 feet that can see may attempt a {@dc 24} Dexterity Saving Throw in order to avert their eyes. A creature who succeeds in averting their eyes is blind until the end of their next turn. Any creatures who fail or choose to look must succeed on a {@dc 30} Charisma Saving Throw or instantly die.

spellcasting.name: Innate Spellcasting
headerEntries: Pale Night's innate spellcasting ability is Charisma (spell save {@dc 26}, +18 to hit with spell attacks). She can innately cast the following spells, requiring no material components:
will: {@spell magic jar} (using her shroud as the vessel)

legendary.name: Move
entries: Pale Night moves up to her maximum speed without provoking attacks of opportunity.

legendary.name: Touch
entries: Pale Night makes an incorporeal touch attack.

legendary.name: Cast a Spell (Costs 2 Actions)
entries: Pale Night casts a spell.

The shrouded creature before you evokes the silhouette of a knight on horseback cloaked in a veil of white cloth leaving nothing truly visible aside from the suggestion of the knight beneath. The truth of what lies beyond the veil, however, is much more horrific.

Unified Horror. When Pale Night traps a creature in her embrace they are often doomed to languish in solitude for eternity as decoration in the Bone Citadel, however, that fate is not always the end. In some cases Pale Night might choose to transform one of these creatures into a demon known as a shrouded knight. These demons appear to be a knight on horseback wrapped in a shroud, much the same as their mother, but the truth is something much more unsettling. The shrouded knight is a single entity, not two creatures. While it takes on this familiar outline, the creature beneath the veil is a single demonic horror that, while only possessing a fraction of Pale Night's essence, is likewise rejected by reality for the wrongness of their form. While their true form is not as impossible to take in as Pale Night herself, their presence is sure to sow chaos and turmoil within the areas of the multiverse they occupy.

Knight's Loyalty. Shrouded knights are absolutely loyal to their creator, Pale Night. They are most typically found defending her lair, the Bone Citadel, but sometimes they are found in other layers of the Abyss acting on behalf of their master. Due to the fact that they most often do battle within the areas of Baphomet's maze that surround the Bone Citadel, they are extremely gifted trackers and incredible at riding down individual targets.

trait.name: Ethereal Sight
entries: The Shrouded Knight can see 60 feet into the Ethereal Plane when it is on the Material Plane, and vice versa.

trait.name: Incorporeal Movement
entries: The shrouded knight can move through other creatures and objects as if they were {@quickref difficult terrain||3}. It takes 5 ({@dice 1d10}) force damage if it ends its turn inside an object.

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: The shrouded knight has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The shrouded knight uses its lesser revelation. It also attacks three times; once with its hooves and twice with its lance.

action.name: Hunter's Lance
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 9} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target.

{@h}11 ({@damage 1d12 + 5}) piercing damage plus 19 ({@damage 3d12}) necrotic damage. If the target is a creature, the shrouded knight knows its precise location for the next 24 hours as long as it is on the same plane of existence as the creature hit by this attack.

action.name: Hooves
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 9} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target.

{@h}10 ({@damage 2d4 + 5}) bludgeoning damage plus 19 ({@damage 3d12}) necrotic damage. If the shrouded knight moves at least 20 ft. straight toward a creature and then hits it with a hooves attack on the same turn, that target must succeed on a {@dc 16} Strength saving throw or be knocked {@condition prone}. If the target is {@condition prone}, the shrouded knight can make another attack with its hooves against it as a bonus action.

action.name: Lesser Revelation
entries: The shrouded knight suppresses its veil, revealing its true form. All creatures within 30 feet that can see may attempt a {@dc 17} Dexterity Saving Throw in order to avert their eyes. A creature who succeeds in averting their eyes is blind until the end of their next turn. Any creatures who fail or choose to look must succeed on a {@dc 20} Charisma Saving Throw or Be {@condition frightened} for 1 minute. A {@condition frightened} target can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the {@condition frightened} condition on itself on a success. If a target's saving throw is successful or the effect ends for it, the target is immune to this shrouded knight's lesser revelation for the next 24 hours.

action.name: Hunter's Maze (1/Day)
entries: The shrouded knight banishes itself, and a creature it can see within 60 feet, into a labyrinthine demiplane. Both creatures remain there for 10 minutes, or until the target escapes the maze. The target can use its action to attempt to escape. When it does so, it makes a {@dc 20} Intelligence Saving Throw. If it succeeds, it escapes (a {@creature minotaur} or {@creature goristro} demon automatically succeeds). When the target escapes, it reappears in the space it left or, if that space is occupied, in the nearest unoccupied space.

The shrouded knight can use its action to try and find the target within the maze. When it does so, it makes a {@dc 15} Intelligence Saving Throw. If it succeeds, it finds the target and is able to make an attack with its lance. It automatically succeeds on this check if the target's location is known to the shrouded knight. When the target escapes, the shrouded knight appears in the space it left or, if that space is occupied, in the nearest unoccupied space at the start of its next turn.

The creature standing before you is tremendous in size, even for a giant. Its charcoal skin is decorated with countless white tattoos depicting various constellations and other celestial bodies, some faded, others fresh and stark. The giant moves with a ponderous look towards the heavens, its hair seemingly flows with no regard for gravity.

Gargantuan Scholars. Eclipse giants truly live up to their namesake in size alone. These creatures are so tremendous that they make even the mighty storm giants look small by comparison. They average approximately forty feet in height and can weigh upwards of thirty-thousand pounds. Many onlookers first assume that due to their apparent bulk and towering physique the giants are mere brutes who rely on strength alone, but that couldn't be further from the truth. Eclipse giants are wanderers at heart who seek to understand the deepest esoteric secrets the world has to offer. This often gets them in trouble, or at least causes troubles for others, as their preoccupied minds tend to notice little else around them beyond the subject of their ponderings which can result in the oblivious destruction of whatever finds itself underfoot.

Marked By The Cosmos. The body of an eclipse giant is marked by numerous tattoos that depict various celestial bodies and star charts. These tattoos can carry many different meanings. Some are a representation of the night sky during an important event in the giant's life such as a great victory in battle, the discovery of something fantastic, or the birth of a child. Others are literal maps encoded in the stars that someone with significant knowledge in astronomy could use to chart a path. Such tattoos typically lead to a location important to the giant's culture that is passed on through the generations. Some say these tattoos grant the giants power over life and death, though to the giants this power is more representative of life's cycles than anything resembling simple necromancy.

Eclipse of the Self. While interested in all manner of cosmological events, the one thing that truly stands at the forefront of eclipse giant culture is the tracking of both lunar and solar eclipses. During an eclipse of any kind the "true self" of every eclipse giant is unlocked. While the giant's "true self" is active they can access a part of their innermost being that is normally kept dormant. Some eclipse giants enter a violent frenzy, becoming nearly unkillable arbiters of death and destruction. Another might begin manically putting pen to parchment, creating written works of art that will define their culture for generations, all while another might be granted vast understanding of the cosmos and temporarily gain the capacity to quickly solve a complex astronomical formula that may have taken years to interpret otherwise. The "true self" of each eclipse giant is different, but it is something they all seek to access as frequently as possible and therefore the prediction of a coming eclipse is of the greatest importance to their species as a whole.

trait.name: Imbue Rock
entries: When the giant throws a rock, it can choose to imbue it with one of the two following magical properties;

items: Destructive Void: Any creature hit by the rock takes an additional 55 ({@damage 10d10}) necrotic damage.

Soothing Light: Any creature that catches the rock is immediately cured of being {@condition blinded}, {@condition deafened}, {@condition paralyzed}, or {@condition poisoned}. The creature also regains 55 ({@dice 10d10}) hit points.

trait.name: Eyes of the Dark
entries: The giant can see through magical darkness as if it were normal darkness.

trait.name: Eclipse Empowered
entries: As long as the giant has direct line of sight to a solar or lunar eclipse, it has advantage on all of its rolls, is immune to being {@condition frightened}, and gains 20 temporary hit points at the start of each of its turns. The giant also gains immunity to nonmagical damage and can't be killed by any instant death effect such as the {@spell power word kill} spell.

trait.name: Wisdom of the Cosmos
entries: The giant adds its Wisdom modifier to initiative rolls and Dexterity Saving Throws.

reaction.name: Rock Catching
entries: When the giant is hit by a thrown weapon attack it can use its reaction to attempt a {@dc 15} Dexterity Saving Throw to deflect or catch the projectile.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The giant attacks three times with its longsword, or once with its longsword and once with a rock.

action.name: Serrated Longsword
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 16} to hit, reach 10 ft., one creature.
{@h}32 ({@damage 5d10 + 10}) slashing damage. This attack is a critical hit on a roll of 19 or 20.

action.name: Rock
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 16} to hit, range 80/300 ft., one target.
{@h}37 ({@damage 4d12 + 10}) bludgeoning damage.

action.name: Snuff Life (1/Day)
entries: The giant twists the essence of life that flows through a living creature it can see within 120 feet. It can then target another living creature that is within 30 feet of the previous target. It can repeat this process until it has targeted up to 9 living creatures. Each target must succeed on a  {@dc 18} Wisdom Saving Throw or be negatively impacted based on their Challenge Rating as shown in the table below. A Player Character's Challenge Rating is equivalent to their current combined class levels.

rows: The target is reduced to 1 hit point.
The target takes 65 ({@damage 10d12}) necrotic damage and is {@condition stunned} until the end of their next turn.
The target takes half as much damage and is not {@condition stunned}.
The target takes 52 ({@damage 8d12}) necrotic damage and is knocked {@condition prone} and their movement speed is reduced to 0 until the end of their next turn.
The target takes half as much damage and is not knocked {@condition prone} and their movement speed is unaffected.
The target takes half as much damage.

spellcasting.name: Innate Spellcasting
headerEntries: The giant's innate spellcasting ability is Wisdom (spell save {@dc 21}, +12 to hit with spell attacks). It can innately cast the following spells, requiring no material components:

legendary.name: Lunar Eclipse
entries: The giant casts moonbeam. If it is already {@status concentration||concentrating} on a moonbeam spell, the giant may instead move the beam up to 60 feet in any direction.

legendary.name: Solar Eclipse (Costs 2 Actions)
entries: The giant glows with a burning light until the start of its next turn. During this time, whenever a creature targets the giant with an attack or ability that requires sight, the target is {@condition blinded} until the end of their turn.

legendary.name: Total Eclipse (Costs 3 Actions)
entries: Until the start of the giant's next turn it is surrounded by a 120 foot area of magical darkness, centred on itself.

The creature standing before you is tremendous in size, even for a giant. Its charcoal skin is decorated with countless white tattoos depicting various constellations and other celestial bodies, some faded, others fresh and stark. The giant moves with a ponderous look towards the heavens, its hair seemingly flows with no regard for gravity.

Gargantuan Scholars. Eclipse giants truly live up to their namesake in size alone. These creatures are so tremendous that they make even the mighty storm giants look small by comparison. They average approximately forty feet in height and can weigh upwards of thirty-thousand pounds. Many onlookers first assume that due to their apparent bulk and towering physique the giants are mere brutes who rely on strength alone, but that couldn't be further from the truth. Eclipse giants are wanderers at heart who seek to understand the deepest esoteric secrets the world has to offer. This often gets them in trouble, or at least causes troubles for others, as their preoccupied minds tend to notice little else around them beyond the subject of their ponderings which can result in the oblivious destruction of whatever finds itself underfoot.

Marked By The Cosmos. The body of an eclipse giant is marked by numerous tattoos that depict various celestial bodies and star charts. These tattoos can carry many different meanings. Some are a representation of the night sky during an important event in the giant's life such as a great victory in battle, the discovery of something fantastic, or the birth of a child. Others are literal maps encoded in the stars that someone with significant knowledge in astronomy could use to chart a path. Such tattoos typically lead to a location important to the giant's culture that is passed on through the generations. Some say these tattoos grant the giants power over life and death, though to the giants this power is more representative of life's cycles than anything resembling simple necromancy.

Eclipse of the Self. While interested in all manner of cosmological events, the one thing that truly stands at the forefront of eclipse giant culture is the tracking of both lunar and solar eclipses. During an eclipse of any kind the "true self" of every eclipse giant is unlocked. While the giant's "true self" is active they can access a part of their innermost being that is normally kept dormant. Some eclipse giants enter a violent frenzy, becoming nearly unkillable arbiters of death and destruction. Another might begin manically putting pen to parchment, creating written works of art that will define their culture for generations, all while another might be granted vast understanding of the cosmos and temporarily gain the capacity to quickly solve a complex astronomical formula that may have taken years to interpret otherwise. The "true self" of each eclipse giant is different, but it is something they all seek to access as frequently as possible and therefore the prediction of a coming eclipse is of the greatest importance to their species as a whole.

trait.name: Imbue Rock
entries: When the giant throws a rock, it can choose to imbue it with one of the two following magical properties;

items: Destructive Void: Any creature hit by the rock takes an additional 55 ({@damage 10d10}) necrotic damage.

Soothing Light: Any creature that catches the rock is immediately cured of being {@condition blinded}, {@condition deafened}, {@condition paralyzed}, or {@condition poisoned}. The creature also regains 55 ({@dice 10d10}) hit points.

trait.name: Eyes of the Dark
entries: The giant can see through magical darkness as if it were normal darkness.

trait.name: Eclipse Empowered
entries: As long as the giant has direct line of sight to a solar or lunar eclipse, it has advantage on all of its rolls, is immune to being {@condition frightened}, and gains 20 temporary hit points at the start of each of its turns. The giant also gains immunity to nonmagical damage and can't be killed by any instant death effect such as the {@spell power word kill} spell.

trait.name: Wisdom of the Cosmos
entries: The giant adds its Wisdom modifier to initiative rolls and Dexterity Saving Throws.

trait.name: Astral Seer
entries: The giant can spend 1 hour studying the stars in order to gain insight into future events. The giant gains accurate information pertaining to one cosmic event or activity that is going to take place within the next 30 days.

reaction.name: Rock Catching
entries: When the giant is hit by a thrown weapon attack it can use its reaction to attempt a {@dc 15} Dexterity Saving Throw to deflect or catch the projectile.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The giant attacks three times with its longsword, or once with its longsword and once with a rock.

action.name: Serrated Longsword
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 16} to hit, reach 10 ft., one creature.
{@h}32 ({@damage 5d10 + 10}) slashing damage. This attack is a critical hit on a roll of 19 or 20.

action.name: Rock
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 16} to hit, range 80/300 ft., one target.
{@h}37 ({@damage 4d12 + 10}) bludgeoning damage.

action.name: Snuff Life {@recharge 6}
entries: The giant twists the essence of life that flows through a living creature it can see within 120 feet. It can then target another living creature that is within 30 feet of the previous target. It can repeat this process until it has targeted up to 9 living creatures. Each target must succeed on a  {@dc 18} Wisdom Saving Throw or be negatively impacted based on their Challenge Rating as shown in the table below. A Player Character's Challenge Rating is equivalent to their current combined class levels.

rows: The target is reduced to 1 hit point.
The target takes 65 ({@damage 10d12}) necrotic damage and is {@condition stunned} until the end of their next turn.
The target takes half as much damage and is not {@condition stunned}.
The target takes 52 ({@damage 8d12}) necrotic damage and is knocked {@condition prone} and their movement speed is reduced to 0 until the end of their next turn.
The target takes half as much damage and is not knocked {@condition prone} and their movement speed is unaffected.
The target takes half as much damage.

The dragon's face bears a large muzzle, its lips curling in a sneer and displaying pronounced canines. Two small horns jut from its head, just above its glowing red eyes. Its tail is long and thin, almost ratlike in appearance. It is covered in midnight blue scales of varying brightness.

Domineering Tyrants. Cobalt dragons are one of, if not the most, domineering of all species of dragon ever to walk the Material Plane. They see the world through a lens of strength, always sizing up other creatures to determine if they are stronger or weaker. They are certainly prideful creatures, but do not allow this pride to get in the way of sound decision making. If they deem a creature to be stronger than them, they may seek a way to subvert that strength, and if subversion isn't possible, they will do their best to avoid them. If they deem themselves to be stronger, which is often the case, they will not hesitate to dominate and subjugate other creatures by any means necessary.

Middle Management. Of the five species of ferrous dragons, cobalt dragons land directly in the middle of their rigid hierarchy. They happily assert their authority over tungsten and nickel dragons, and begrudgingly follow the commands of iron and chromium dragons.

Proud Parents. Despite their general tendency towards cruelty, cobalt dragons are actually capable and loving parents. When a new brood of wyrmlings hatches, the parents will care for their offspring for many years until they are old enough to fend for themselves, at which point they will be thrown from the nest and sent out to claim lands of their own.
A Cobalt Dragon's Lair.

Cobalt Dragons live within the deep forests and sprawling jungles of the world. They are capable of nesting in many different locations but prefer to nest in deep caves or tunnel networks buried beneath thick forest growth. They often compete for territory with green and orange dragons, making them natural rivals. In addition to wealth and other resources, a cobalt dragon's hoard is bound to be filled with attendants and other creatures the dragon has subjugated into servitude under threats of violence. This often includes less powerful dragons.

trait.name: Amphibious
entries: The cobalt dragon wyrmling can breathe air and water.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 6} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}9 ({@damage 1d10 + 4}) piercing damage.

action.name: Breath Weapon {@recharge 5}
entries: The dragon uses one of the following breath weapons.

items.name: Magnetic Breath
items.entry: The dragon exhales a line of magnetic energy  in a 30-foot line. Each creature in that area must make a {@dc 13} Dexterity saving throw, taking 22 ({@damage 4d10}) force damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one. A creature who fails their save is also knocked {@condition prone} and pushed 5 feet away from the line in a direction of the dragon's choosing.

items.name: Rimedeath Fog
items.entry: The dragon exhales sickly blue fog in a 15-foot cone. Each creature in that area must make a {@dc 13} Constitution saving throw, taking 10 ({@damage 3d6}) poison damage and 10 ({@damage 3d6}) cold damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one. A creature who fails this save by 5 or more is {@condition poisoned}. While {@condition poisoned} in this way the creature is {@condition deafened}. A {@condition poisoned} creature can repeat their Constitution Saving Throw to end the {@condition poisoned} status every time they complete a long rest.

monster.name: Chia Golem

entries: This bizarre creature is a golem crafted with a body formed from baked clay, then filled with soil and seeds.

VARIABLE APPEARANCE. As created creatures, the appearance of chia golems span a wide array of varied forms. In noble courts or royal estates they often appear as giant rabbits, mice, lions, unicorns, dragons, or even statuesque armed guards. If created for a more sinister purpose they may appear as minotaurs, giant insects, or simply as faceless amalgams created with only utility in mind. More so than most golems, these creatures are truly a reflection of the one who crafts them. The other major factor in the appearance are the seeds planted within the creature. Most often various types of grass or hanging vines are used, however, some golems are created with seeds from plants with special qualities that can be floral, poisonous, bioluminescent, or even magical in nature.

HIGH MAINTENANCE. Unlike most other golems, chia golems require a high degree of upkeep in order to function properly. They must be kept hydrated and topped up with fertiliser to ensure the plants living within their housing are kept alive. This is a price many are willing to pay, however, since the initial cost of creating a chia golem is relatively low compared to other constructs.

DRUIDIC ORIGINS. Another way in which these golems differ from other golems is that instead of being created by clerics and wizards, chia golems have roots in the tradition of druidic magic. They were originally crafted to serve as guards for druid groves. Their appearance and ability to move at a near imperceptibly slow speed made them a natural fit for grove guardians. Some druids would even plant extremely dangerous plants with their golems such as yellow musk creepers or corpse flowers in their golems which would merge with the golem's magic, allowing the golem to control the plant's actions and making it infinitely more dangerous.

entries.name: Creating a Chia Golem
entries: To create a chia golem one must first craft the body using clay. The clay is then baked in order to harden its form  into a permanent shape. This typically requires about 1,000 pounds of clay, though it can be more if the chosen form is exceptionally large. Once the body is crafted, it must be filled with soul and seeds of whatever variety the creator chooses. Then, by casting plant growth,  animate objects, and grasping vine on the body it will be  ready to become a golem. The final step is watering the golem regularly for one month until the seeds have matured and the golem rises on its own.

languages: Understands the language of its creator but can't speak

immune.note: from nonmagical attacks that aren't Adamantine

trait.name: Immutable Form
entries: The golem is immune to any spell or effect that would alter its form.

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: The golem has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

trait.name: Magic Weapons
entries: The golem's weapon attacks are magical.

trait.name: Organic Magic Immunity
entries: Chia golems are immune to the effects and damage normally imposed by plant-based spells such as {@spell entangle}, {@spell grasping vine}, or {@spell hail of thorns}.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The golem makes two slam attacks.

action.name: Slam
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 8} to hit, reach 5 ft., one creature. {@h}16 ({@damage 2d10 + 5}) bludgeoning damage.

action.name: Overgrowth (1/Day)
entries: The plants growing on the golem's body erupt outward, transforming the area within 20 feet of the golem into difficult terrain. All creatures in the area when the golem does this must succeed on a {@dc 15} Strength Saving Throw or be {@condition restrained} (escape {@dc 15}) by the plants.

bonus.name: Grasping Vine
entries: A vine sprouts from the golem's body and whips towards a single creature within 30 feet of the golem that it can see. The target must succeed on a {@dc 15} Dexterity Saving Throw or be {@condition grappled} (escape {@dc 15}) by the golem and if it is large or smaller, get pulled 20 feet closer towards it. If the target is already {@condition grappled} by the golem, it automatically fails its Dexterity Saving Throw. The golem can have up to one creature {@condition grappled} by its vine at a time.

action.name: Overgrowth (1/Day)
entries: The plants growing on the golem's body erupt outward, transforming the area within 20 feet of the golem into difficult terrain. All creatures in the area when the golem does this must succeed on a {@dc 15} Strength Saving Throw or be {@condition restrained} (escape {@dc 15}) by the plants.

action.name: Poison Cloud {@recharge 5}
entries: The golem shakes its body and unleashes a swarm of poisonous spores into the air. All creatures who need to breath within 60 feet of the golem must succeed on a DC 15 Constitution Saving Throw or become Poisoned for 1 minute. A creature poisoned in this Way also contracts the Sprouting Madness disease.

This disease causes small plants of the same variety housed within the chia golem to slowly sprout from the creature's skin. Every morning when they wake up there are {@dice 10d6} new sprouts on their body. Once the number of sprouts is equal to or higher than 300, the creature must succeed on a DC 10 Constitution Saving Throw or die. If the creature succeeds, the disease ends, however, their creature type is permanently changed to plant, they gain resistance to poison damage, and vulnerability to fire damage.

If any attempt is made to cut the sprouts from the afflicted creature's body, they will  simply grow back the next day and the disease will  become more aggressive, adding an additional {@dice d6} to the amount of sprouts that appear each morning.

bonus.name: Grasping Vine
entries: A vine sprouts from the golem's body and whips towards a single creature within 30 feet of the golem that it can see. The target must succeed on a {@dc 15} Dexterity Saving Throw or be {@condition grappled} (escape {@dc 15}) by the golem and if it is large or smaller, get pulled 20 feet closer towards it. If the target is already {@condition grappled} by the golem, it automatically fails its Dexterity Saving Throw. The golem can have up to one creature {@condition grappled} by its vine at a time.

The small humanoid creature before you is reminiscent of a goblin, though its limbs stretch well beyond a goblin's proportions, and it boasts a robust physique that indicates it as no stranger to tests of strength. Its skin is a deep purple, lined with black stripes. Its face is almost bat-like with a wide maw filled with sharp, tightly packed teeth. The creature's massive ears ever so slightly twitch and shutter, as though it is listening to myriad sounds imperceptible to most.

BORN TO DIE. Vril are the result of intergenerational experimentation on goblins conducted by insidious Drow Elf wizards. The idea was to raise up a species of goblin that could act as a powerful caste of minions for their schemes, with the intent of using them as loyal shock troops and guards for areas outside the city. While the brutal training and rigorous experimentation certainly managed to yield results, the vril would quickly prove to be much more independent than the wizards could imagine.

ROGUE SPECIES. Some Vril still work at the behest of their creators, due in part to the fact that they were genetically modified with magic making them  vulnerable to poison, a tool which their creators have access to in abundance. Despite this setback, the majority of Vril have since escaped the purpose originally intended for their species and have found themselves decidedly acclimated to life in The Underdark. Using their extremely sharp sense of hearing to navigate the cavernous geography of The Underdark, and their powerful shrieks  as a method of communication over vast distances, few vril can control wide areas of territory with relative ease.

THOUGHTFUL COMBATANTS. Unlike standard goblins, Vril approach most problems with an inquisitive mind, and a level of situational awareness that even Hobgoblins can't help but admire. They will always try to observe an opponent and attempt to glean what kind of weaponry they are using before engaging with an enemy. This helps ensure that they can make proper use of their skinshift ability in order to shrug off strikes that would otherwise see them dead. They are fond of ambush tactics as well, making use of their powerful shrieks before jumping into battle with vicious intent. How the Vril fit in with the other goblinoid races still has yet to be seen, though some scholars believe they may possess the strength of both body and mind to challenge the Hobgoblins for dominance, and if they should manage to find common ground and cooperation, the enemies of goblinkind are bound to wind up in deep trouble.

trait.name: Echolocation
entries: The vril can't use its blindsight while {@condition deafened}.

trait.name: Sunlight Sensitivity
entries: While in sunlight, the vril has disadvantage on attack rolls, as well as on Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) checks that rely on sight.

action.name: War Pick
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 4} to hit, reach 5 ft., one creature. {@h}6 ({@damage 1d8 + 2}) piercing damage or 7 ({@damage 1d10 + 2}) piercing damage if used two-handed.

action.name: Javelin
entries: {@atk mw,rw} {@hit +4} to hit, reach 5 ft. or range 30/120 ft., one target. {@h}5 ({@damage 1d6 + 2}) piercing damage.

action.name: Shriek {@recharge 5}
entries: The vril emits a horribly shriek in either a 15 foot radius centred on itself, or in a 30 foot cone. Any non-vril creature in the area who can hear takes 9 ({@dice 2d8}) points of thunder damage, or half as much on a successful {@dc 13} Constitution Saving Throw. A creature that fails their save is {@condition deafened} for 1 minute. A creature that fails their save by 5 or more is {@condition stunned} until the start of the vril's next turn.

bonus.name: Skinshift (1/Day)
entries: The vril alters the consistency of its skin, granting it resistance to bludgeoning, piercing, or slashing damage. This effect lasts until the vril takes a long rest.

trait.name: Echolocation
entries: The vril can't use its blindsight while {@condition deafened}.

trait.name: Sunlight Sensitivity
entries: While in sunlight, the vril has disadvantage on attack rolls, as well as on Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) checks that rely on sight.

trait.name: Tactician
entries: The vril leader adds its proficiency bonus to initiative rolls made by any nonhostile creatures within 60 feet, including itself.

trait.name: Ambush Expert
entries: When the vril leader or any nonhostile creatures within 60 feet of it make a damage roll against a surprised creature, they add {@damage 2d6} damage of the same type dealt by their attack to the target.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The vril leader makes three melee attacks. Alternatively, it can make two ranged attacks with its javelins.

action.name: War Pick
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 4} to hit, reach 5 ft., one creature. {@h}6 ({@damage 1d8 + 2}) piercing damage or 7 ({@damage 1d10 + 2}) piercing damage if used two-handed.

action.name: Javelin
entries: {@atk mw,rw} {@hit +4} to hit, reach 5 ft. or range 30/120 ft., one target. {@h}5 ({@damage 1d6 + 2}) piercing damage.

action.name: Shriek {@recharge 5}
entries: The vril emits a horribly shriek in either a 30 foot radius centred on itself, or in a 60 foot cone. Any non-vril creature in the area who can hear takes 18 ({@dice 4d8}) points of thunder damage, or half as much on a successful {@dc 15} Constitution Saving Throw. A creature that fails their save is {@condition deafened} for 1 minute. A creature that fails their save by 5 or more is {@condition stunned} until the start of the vril's next turn.

action.name: Warrior's Insight {@recharge 5}
entries: The vril leader takes stock of its current situation and formulates a plan of action before bellowing commands to its allies. For the next minute, whenever a nonhostile creature within 60 feet of the vril leader makes an attack roll, saving throw, or skill check, as long as it is following the commands of the vril leader, the creature adds {@dice 1d6} to its roll provided it can hear and understand the vril leader. A creature can only benefit from one leadership die at a time. The effect ends if the vril leader is {@condition incapacitated}.

bonus.name: Skinshift (3/Day)
entries: The vril alters the consistency of its skin, granting it resistance to bludgeoning, piercing, or slashing damage. This effect lasts until the vril takes a long rest.

Its skin is a deep purple, lined with black stripes. Its face is almost bat-like with a wide maw filled with sharp, tightly packed teeth. How the Vril fit in with the other goblinoid races still has yet to be seen, though some scholars believe they may possess the strength of both body and mind to challenge the Hobgoblins for dominance, and if they should manage to find common ground and cooperation, the enemies of goblinkind are bound to wind up in deep trouble.

BLOODSWORN. Some vril have taken to dabbling in magic of their own, using it to rid themselves of the vulnerabilities thrust upon them by their creators. It is unclear precisely where the first bloodsworm came from, but many scholars believe these special members of vril society have entered into a collective pact with a more powerful entity. It is possible that this entity is Maglubiyet himself, the god of all goblins, and that this pact serves as not just a boon to the vril, but also as a formal vow of fealty to the god of goblinoids. Yet it is also possible that they have fond communion with some other entity, currently unknown to the wider world, and that they now serve a much darker purpose on behalf of something supremely sinister.

trait.name: Echolocation
entries: The vril can't use its blindsight while {@condition deafened}.

trait.name: Sunlight Sensitivity
entries: While in sunlight, the vril has disadvantage on attack rolls, as well as on Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) checks that rely on sight.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The vril leader makes two melee attacks. Alternatively, it can make two ranged attacks with its blood lance.

action.name: Bloodlance
entries: Ranged Magic Attack: {@hit 7} to hit, range 120 ft., one creature. {@h}9 ({@damage 1d10 + 4}) Force damage, or 9 ({@damage 1d10 + 4}) Necrotic damage and the vril bloodsworn gains temporary hit points equal to half the necrotic damage dealt.

action.name: Quarterstaff
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 5} to hit, reach 5 ft., one creature. {@h}5 ({@damage 1d6 + 2}) Bludgeoning damage or 6 ({@damage 1d8 + 3}) Bludgeoning damage if used two-handed. The target must succeed on a {@dc 15} Dexterity Saving Throw or be knocked {@condition prone}.

action.name: Shriek {@recharge 5}
entries: The vril emits a horribly shriek in either a 30 foot radius centred on itself, or in a 60 foot cone. Any non-vril creature in the area who can hear takes 18 ({@dice 4d8}) points of thunder damage, or half as much on a successful {@dc 15} Constitution Saving Throw. A creature that fails their save is {@condition deafened} for 1 minute. A creature that fails their save by 5 or more is {@condition stunned} until the start of the vril's next turn.

action.name: Resounding Thunder (1/Day)
entries: The vril calls forth a deafening blast of sound in a 20-foot-radius sphere, emanating from a point of its choosing within 120 feet. Each creature in the area takes 21 ({@damage 6d6}) Thunder damage, or half as much on a {@dc 15} Constitution Saving Throw. A creature who fails their save is also {@condition deafened} for 1 hour. Creatures who fail their save by 5 or more are also knocked {@condition prone}.

bonus.name: Skinshift (3/Day)
entries: The vril alters the consistency of its skin, granting it resistance to bludgeoning, piercing, or slashing damage. This effect lasts until the vril takes a long rest.

bonus.name: Death Mark (3/Day)
entries: The vril uses its {@status concentration} to place a  curse on a creature it can see within 90 feet, marking it for death in the name of its master. For the next hour, or until the vril's {@status concentration} is broken, the cursed creature takes an additional {@damage 1d4} Necrotic damage every time it takes damage. If the target dies while being targeted by this curse, their soul is taken to the domain of the vril's master and they can't be brought back to life by any means short of a Wish spell until their soul is no longer held captive.

This massive, fishlike, vaguely humanoid creature has a body coated in scales and slime. The creature's bulbous eyes dart around, inspecting everything within the monster's domain. Its limbs are thin and gaunt compared to the rest of its body, but its imposing maw is lined with countless razor-sharp teeth, and looks large enough to swallow a horse in one bite.

GIFT OF THE SEA MOTHER. Many kuo-toa venerate and respect massive sea creatures such as leviathans and krakens. They often dream of attaining such tremendous power and high regard in the eyes of The Sea Mother. Among the many dreamers, some are chosen by fate to ascend beyond their wildest aspirations and actually become massive predators of the dark waters that run through The Underdark. Each kuo-toa leviathan was once truly a remarkable individual among their kind, and through ascension rites granted to only the most fanatical, is a kuo-toa leviathan born. The process sees them grow upwards of 20 feet in height, eschewing many of the features that make traversing the land less difficult in favour of a body more capable of navigating the deepest parts of the ocean.

INSATIABLE APPETITES. These monstrous beings have monstrous appetites. They will kill and eat just about anything they come across, finding few natural predators if any. When hunger strikes, the kuo-toa leviathan becomes nearly mindless in its pursuit of meat. In some cases, if their hunger goes unsatiated for long enough, they may even resort to consuming smaller kuo-toa.

VENERABLE COLOSSI. Kuo-toa leviathans possess an almost sacred place in kuo-toa culture. They spend almost all of their time in the water, only emerging to the land when they are called to some task by their goddess or their brethren. Few among the kuo-toa ever have the honour of actually meeting a kuo-toa leviathan, and of those who do, even fewer live to tell the tale.

EVOLVING SPECIES. Tales tell of ancient kuo-toa leviathans that have been active for centuries. Such beings are said to have continued to grow and evolve, developing strang and uncanny features that better help them exist and explore in the vast emptiness at the bottom of the ocean. What purpose these individuals may pursue, and why, is a mystery even to the kuo-toa they progenerate from.

trait.name: Amphibious
entries: The kuo toa leviathan can breathe air and water.

trait.name: Otherworldly Perception
entries: The kuo toa leviathan can sense the presence of any creature within 120 feet of it that is {@condition invisible} or on the Ethereal Plane. It can pinpoint such a creature that is moving.

trait.name: Slippery
entries: The kuo-toa has advantage on ability checks and saving throws made to escape a grapple.

trait.name: Sunlight Sensitivity
entries: While in sunlight, the kuo toa leviathan has disadvantage on attack rolls, as well as on Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) checks that rely on sight.

bonus.name: Regurgitate
entries: The kuo-toa regurgitates a creature it has swallowed, causing it to fall {@condition prone} in a space within 10 feet of the kuo-toa.

reaction.name: Reflexive Dodge
entries: Trigger: The kuo-toa is hit by an attack while it is submerged in water. Response: The kuo-toa moves up to half its swim speed in a straight line in any direction without provoking attacks of opportunity.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The kuo-toa attacks once with its bite and twice with its claws.

action.name: Bite
entries: Melee Attack Roll: {@hit 13} to hit, reach 5 ft. {@h}26 ({@damage 4d8 + 8}) Piercing damage and if the target is Huge or smaller, they are {@condition grappled} (escape {@dc 18}) in the kuo-toa's mouth. The kuo-toa can have one creature {@condition grappled} in its mouth at a time.

action.name: Claws
entries: Melee Attack Roll: {@hit 13} to hit, reach 10 ft. {@h}17 ({@damage 2d8 + 8}) Slashing damage and the target must succeed on a {@dc 15} Constitution Saving Throw or become {@condition poisoned} for 1 minute.

action.name: Swallow
entries: The  kuo-toa makes one bite attack against a Large or smaller creature it is grappling. If the attack hits, the target takes the bite's damage, the target is swallowed, and the grapple ends. While swallowed, the creature is {@condition blinded} and {@condition restrained}, it has total cover against attacks and other effects outside the tarrasque, and it takes 35 ({@damage 10d6}) acid damage at the start of each of the  kuo-toa's turns.

If the kuo-toa takes 45 damage or more on a single turn from a creature inside it, the  kuo-toa must succeed on a {@dc 22} Constitution saving throw at the end of that turn or regurgitate all swallowed creatures, which fall {@condition prone} in a space within 10 feet of the  kuo-toa. If the  kuo-toa dies, a swallowed creature is no longer {@condition restrained} by it and can escape from the corpse by using 30 feet of movement, exiting {@condition prone}.

action.name: Blinding Flash {@recharge 5}
entries: The kuo-toa shields its eyes with an opaque, black membrane and ignites its lure. All creatures within 30 feet of the kuo-toa must succeed on a {@dc 18} Constitution Saving Throw or be Blinded for 1 minute. A creature who fails this save by 5 or more is also {@condition stunned} until the start of the kuo-toa's next turn.

action.name: Enticing Lure (3/Day)
entries: The kuo-toa ignites its lure for up to one hour, which dangles in front of its gaping maw. Any creature who sees the lure must succeed on a {@dc 18} Wisdom Saving Throw or be Charmed by the kuo-toa. A creature {@condition charmed} in this way is compelled to approach, using their entire turn to get as close as possible to the kuo-toa's lure. A creature who ends their turn within 5 feet of the kuo-toa is {@condition paralyzed} for 1 hour, or until the kuo-toa deactivates its lure. The lure is immediately deactivated if the kuo-toa moves or makes an attack. Any creature who succeeds on their Saving Throw to resist the kuo-toa's enticing lure is immune to the enticing lure of that kuo-toa for 24 hours.

The humanoid creature standing before you wears tattered robes and a wide brimmed hat, all fashioned from earth toned fabric and leather. The form underneath is lanky and its skin is pale. The creature's eyes are entirely black, and they sparkle like a distant starfield.

BORN OF THE LAND. Like many fey creatures, ruin chanters are spirits born of the land they occupy. Rather than being brought to life by the latent energy of an ancient forest or forgotten mountain, ruin chanters are made manifest by immense sadness, loss, and a profound sense of solitude. They are melancholic spirits who seek to preserve the dormant memories that lay trapped within aged ruins and abandoned places. They subsist on a diet of ash and dust, and they sleep on a bed of rubble. To them, these things are not only acceptable, but enjoyable.

ANCIENT PLACES. Ruin chanters can be found anywhere that once held life, but is now abandoned for one reason or another. Lost cities, ancient temples, and toppled fortresses are all among their favourite haunts. They protect these places with an unblinking vigilance. They care little about things happening outside of their domain, and will be openly hostile towards anyone they believe is seeking to raid their home for treasure. Such encounters usually end in death for the intruders, though the chanter typically won't cause undue suffering. They will simply do whatever they must to return the ruin to a state of undisturbed silence as fast as possible. If another creature enters the chanter's ruin with good intentions and conducts themselves with respect, the chanter may be willing to converse with them, and is very unlikely to attack unprovoked.

RESTORATION. Ruin chanters will abide the presence of any constructs, undead, or other creatures who naturally occupy their home. They will also tolerate creatures who enter the ruins with intent to restore or maintain them in some way, often making themselves known and actively cooperating with such individuals. They also seek out other ruin chanters for companionship, though such meetings are rare, and territory between chanter's is always respected. They communicate with one another over vast distances using esoteric songs sung in Sylvan.
MAGIC ITEMS

Many ruin chanters have found powerful magic items within the places they inhabit. Consider what magic items a ruin chanter may have discovered in the ruin which it occupies, and consider adding them to the creature's stat block. Just keep in mind any items the creature is carrying may be looted by adventurers who best the creature in combat.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The chanter makes three melee attacks.

action.name: Adamantine Mace
entries: Melee Attack Roll: {@hit 9} to hit, reach 5 ft. {@h}7 ({@damage 1d6 + 4}) Bludgeoning damage plus 4 ({@damage 1d8}) Necrotic damage.

action.name: Curse of Infirmity {@recharge 5}
entries: The chanter unleashes a guttural curse and points a finger at a creature it can see within 60 feet. The target must succeed on a {@dc 18} Wisdom Saving Throw or be cursed by the chanter's Curse of Infirmity. When the curse is first placed, the chanter must choose one of the two following options to be applied;

items.name: Infirmity of Body
items.entry: The target's hair turns white, their skin wrinkles, and their posture stoops.The target has disadvantage on {@dice  D 20} Tests using  Strength, Dexterity, and Constitution.

items.name: Infirmity of Mind
items.entry: The target has disadvantage on {@dice  D 20} Tests using  Intelligence, Wisdom, and Charisma.

entries: The curse lasts for one hour, or until removed. The chanter cannot place both possible effects of the curse simultaneously on the same creature.

action.name: Rusting Grasp {@recharge 5}
entries: The chanter touches and corrodes a nonmagical ferrous metal object it can see within 5 feet of it. If the object isn't being worn or carried, the touch destroys a 1-foot cube of it. If the object is being worn or carried by a creature, the creature can make a {@dc 16} Dexterity saving throw to avoid the chanter's touch.

If the object touched is either metal armor or a metal shield being worn or carried, it takes a permanent and cumulative −1 penalty to the AC it offers. Armor reduced to an AC of 10 or a shield that drops to a +0 bonus is destroyed. If the object touched is a held metal weapon, the weapon takes a permanent and cumulative −1 penalty to damage rolls. If its penalty drops to −5, the weapon is destroyed.

trait.name: Call Ruin Elemental (1/Week)
entries: The chanter performs a ritual that involves singing an ancient dirge which imbues some of their feywild magic into the surrounding ruins. Over the course of an hour, bits and pieces of the ruins will coalesce into a singular entity, resulting in the creation of a new {@creature ruin elemental|dungeondadstatblocks}. The elemental is loyal to the chanter until it dies. If the chanter is slain, the ruin elemental will continue to protect the from which it was conjured.

bonus.name: Chanter's Inspiration (4/Day)
entries: The chanter inspires another creature within 60 feet of itself who can hear them. The creature adds {@dice 1d10} to their next failed {@dice  D 20} Test.

bonus.name: Dash
entries: The chanter moves up to its move speed.

reaction.name: Counterchant
entries: Trigger: The chanter or another creature within 30 feet of it fails a saving throw against an effect that applies the Charmed or Frightened condition. Response: The save is rerolled with advantage.

The hulking pile of rubble begins to shudder and assemble itself into a massive creature with a vaguely humanoid shape. Its rocky form consists of countless components ranging from tremendous statues and castle archways to individual cobblestones and door knockers, all taken from the ruins it was created in.

LOYAL GUARDIANS. Ruin elementals are created by ruin chanters in order to act as guardians of the place their creator dwells. They are generally passive and patient creatures, but will quickly turn violent when they detect the presence of a trespasser within the area they protect. The only way to guarantee a ruin elemental's grace is to become ingratiated with the ruin chanter who created them.

ETERNAL BEINGS. As elemental beings, they do not age or succumb to the needs of a biological creature. Even after their creator has died, a ruin elemental will continue to protect its home until destroyed.

trait.name: False Appearance
entries: While the elemental is {@condition prone}, as long as it remains motionless, it is indistinguishable from a pile of rubble.

trait.name: Siege Monster
entries: The ruin elemental deals double damage to objects and structures.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The creature makes two slam attacks.

action.name: Slam
entries: Melee Attack Roll: {@hit 12} to hit, reach 10 ft. {@h}17 ({@damage 2d8 + 8}) Bludgeoning damage.

action.name: Rock
entries: Ranged Attack Roll: {@hit 12} to hit, range 60/240  ft. {@h}30 ({@damage 4d10 + 8}) Bludgeoning damage.

bonus.name: Shockwave {@recharge 5}
entries: The elemental strikes the ground and creates a shockwave in a 20-foot radius centred on itself. All other creatures in the area are pushed 5 feet away from the elemental and knocked {@condition prone} unless they can succeed on a {@dc 16} Dexterity Saving Throw.

With a massive muzzle, even for a dragon, the chromium dragon presents an imposing visage decorated by two ornate horns and a brilliant neck-furl. Its expression is that of a sneering apex predator, holding malice and contempt for other beings behind its brilliant red eyes. The dragon's brilliant mirror-like scales gleam like liquid metal, reflecting the nearby terrain.

GREED IS GOOD. Chromium dragons are among the most avaricious draconic creatures to ever walk the earth. Were it not for their rarity, they would likely be known as the greediest family of true dragons, even surpassing that of the notoriously covetous red dragons. The idea that they should dominate, procure, and otherwise possess anything and everything that falls beneath their gaze is the driving principle behind most chromium dragon schemes. Were it not for the slightly more powerful iron dragons keeping them in check, the unbounded desire for more within each chromium dragon would certainly spin out of control.

SHINY AND CHROME. Chromium dragons are born with scales that resemble a dull silver colour. As they age, their scales become more polished and reflective, ultimately becoming mirror-like. This has led to many instances where a chromium dragon is mistaken for a silver or mercury dragon, a mistake that often ends in disaster. Their shiny scales are not just for show, however. Chromium dragons use their scales in combat to get more varied angles on potential opponents, making them very difficult to sneak up on. They are also able to use magic in order to easily blend in with their surroundings.
CHROMIUM DRAGON LAIRS

Chromium dragons create lairs in frozen wastes and snow-capped mountains. They often use their icy breath to and magic to create frozen walls and structures that can accommodate them and their massive treasure hoard. The dragon's lair is also bound to be filled with dangerous traps and winding passageways of polished ice that make it extremely difficult for interlopers to navigate their way to the dragon's valuables, or escape if they happen to be so lucky. Chromium dragon lairs often include the following features;
Labyrinthine pathways with walls made from ice.
Reflective surfaces meant to confound and confuse.
A massive treasure hoard, even by draconic standards, all extremely well organised by category and function.
Chambers which are hidden behind thick walls of ice that only the dragon, or a very determined creature, can access.
CHROMIUM DRAGON WYRMLINGS

As a newly born chromium dragon, the world at large may seem quite large, but it's only a matter of time before their avaricious instinct kicks in and that big world becomes nothing more than a series of conquests to collect treasure from. Wyrmlings typically stay with their parents until they are old enough to hunt for themselves, at which point they set out into the world with the hopes of building up a treasure hoard of their own.

trait.name: Legendary Resistance (1/Day in Lair)
entries: If the dragon fails a saving throw, it can choose to succeed instead.

trait.name: Mirrored Sight
entries: The dragon is immune to being {@condition flanked|FleeMortals} or {@status surprised}.

action.name: Rend
entries: Melee Attack Roll: {@hit 8} to hit, reach 10 ft. {@h}9 ({@dice 1d8 + 5}) Slashing  plus 3 ({@damage 1d6}) Cold damage.

action.name: Crystalline Breath {@recharge 5}
entries: Dexterity Saving Throw: {@dc 14}, each creature in a 15-foot Cone or a 30-foot long, 5-foot wide Line. Failure: 24 ({@damage 7d6}) cold damage. Success: Half damage.

spellcasting.name: Spellcasting
headerEntries: The dragon casts one of the following spells, requiring no material components, using Charisma as the spellcasting ability (spell save {@dc 14})

1e: {@spell flesh to stone} (but target is turned into crystal instead of stone)

reaction.name: Blinding Flash
entries: Trigger: The dragon uses its Legendary Resistance Trait, or is hit with a ranged attack. Response - Constitution Saving Throw: {@dc 15}, each creature in a 30-foot-radius Sphere centred on the dragon. Failure: 7 ({@damage 2d6}) Radiant damage and Blind until the end of their next turn.

reaction.name: Reflective Scales
entries: Trigger: The dragon is  targeted by a magic missile spell, a line spell, or a spell that requires a ranged attack roll. Response: Roll a {@dice d6}. On a 1 to 5, the dragon is unaffected. On a 6, the dragon is unaffected, and the effect is reflected back at the caster as though it originated from the dragon, turning the caster into the target.

reaction.name: Rend Retaliation
entries: Trigger: The dragon takes damage. Response: The dragon makes a Rend attack.

Its expression is that of a sneering apex predator, holding malice and contempt for other beings behind its brilliant red eyes. Chambers which are hidden behind thick walls of ice that only the dragon, or a very determined creature, can access.
YOUNG CHROMIUM DRAGONS

At this stage of life, a young chromium dragon is likely just starting to establish its claim in the world. The dragon will certainly have attained the service of some lesser creatures to act as minions, and likely has a healthy hoard of treasure starting to pile up. At this point in the dragon's lifecycle, if it hasn't found a lair already, it is bound to wind up seeking out a place to call its own.

A massive treasure hoard, even by draconic standards, all extremely well organised by category and function.
Chambers which are hidden behind thick walls of ice that only the dragon, or a very determined creature, can access.
ADULT CHROMIUM DRAGONS

An adult chromium dragon is a creature that is bound to be known and feared in the lands it occupies. Through sheer force of will, it is bound to be sitting at the top of whatever established order may exist within its domain, and if there isn't one, it will be the one to set the pecking order. Leaders of any sentient creatures within its lands are bound to pay tribute to the great dragon, and as such its hoard will rival that of entire kingdoms.

entries: If the dragon fails a saving throw, it can choose to succeed instead.
