ANCIENT CHROMIUM DRAGONS

Chromium dragons are exceedingly rare, and ancient chromium dragons likely number in the single digits. Each one of these monumental creatures is bound to have a hoard of treasure so large, it may be unrecognisable as such. Chromium dragons of this age and stature may consider entire kingdoms to be a part of their hoard, and all the treasure within them, and it is never enough.

entries: If the dragon fails a saving throw, it can choose to succeed instead.

entries: A gaunt, towering figure looms before you. Its skeletal frame is draped in folded skin and its bald head is covered in lesions and sickly growths. Its mouth is a seeping wound and its eyes are twin points of burning light.

DEMOTED DEVILS. Gulthirs are unique in the hierarchy of devils in that they are somewhat removed from the rigid chain of command to which all devils must adhere. They are not a fiendish form that a lesser devil can be promoted into, but rather a lowly form that devils can be demoted to when they fail their superiors in some way. Transformation into a gulthir doesn't strip the devil of its identity or memories, and is not intended to be a permanent situation (most of the time). It is up to the newly demoted gulthir to once again prove themselves worthy of their station and earn back the status they once held.

FEARED BY ALL. Gulthirs are often put to work as a punitive force within fiendish society. They are feared by all lesser devils because they are one of the few creatures capable of completely destroying a devil, soul and all, even when they are not on their home plane of existence. When a gulthir swallows a creature, its digestive fluids have an effect similar to spells of domination on the victim, however, if the swallowed creature is a devil the gulthir can digest them and absorb their essence, completely destroying the original creature and empowering the gulthir. Gulthirs can also choose for a digested fiend to be reborn as another gulthir, which they will promptly disgorge as a crude means of propagating their species.

STATUS SYMBOLS. Treasure and magic items are seen as a symbol of status in most cultures, and the same is true among devils. Gulthirs greedily cling to any and all treasure they can find, adorning themselves in jewels and finery as a means of altering the perception of others to think more highly of them. They often carry trinkets in their gizzard that are especially precious in order to protect them from rivals.

trait.name: Gulthir Gizzard
entries: A gulthir's gizzard can hold one creature at a time. Any creature swallowed by the gluthir is immediately {@condition restrained} and placed under the effects of a {@spell Dominate Monster} spell controlled by the gulthir. If the creature is disgorged by the gulthir, it can attempt to make a {@dc 17} Wisdom Saving Throw at the end of each of its turns to end the effects of the spell. The effect ends if the gulthir is killed or if the dominated creature's eyes are washed with holy water.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The creature makes a bite attack and a claw attack.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atkr m} {@hit 7} to hit, reach 10 ft. {@h}21 ({@damage 4d6 + 4}) Slashing damage and the target is {@condition grappled} (escape {@dc 15}).

action.name: Claw
entries: {@atkr m} {@hit 7} to hit, reach 10 ft. {@h}7 ({@damage 1d6 + 4}) Bludgeoning damage and the target is {@condition grappled} (escape {@dc 15}).

action.name: Disgorge
entries: The gulthir spews a creature held in its gizzard into an unoccupied space within 5 feet of it. The creature's eyes are covered with an ichorous white film.

spellcasting.name: Spellcasting
headerEntries: The gulthir's innate spellcasting ability is Wisdom (spell save {@dc 15}, +7 to hit with spell attacks). It can innately cast the following spells, requiring no material components:

reaction.name: Ingest Evil
entries: {@actTrigger} The gulthir starts its turn with a fiend in its gizzard. {@actResponse} The fiend is digested, instantly destroying the creature. The gulthir gains temporary hit points equal to the current hit points of the digested fiend before it is destroyed and the gulthir has advantage on saving throws for one minute.

reaction.name: Spawn Gulthir
entries: {@actTrigger} The gulthir starts its turn with a fiend in its gizzard. {@actResponse} The fiend is transformed into a new gulthir.

reaction.name: Swallow Whole
entries: {@actTrigger} The gulthir starts its turn with a creature that is smaller than it {@condition grappled}. {@actResponse} The creature is swallowed whole and placed in the gulthir's gizzard.

The dragon before you has soft grey metallic scales that catch the sunlight in such a way as to suggest a precious metal. Their two horns jut out, slightly curved as if swept back, but still long and imposing. Despite the dragon's small size, it has a look of malice and rage within its eyes.

SMALL BUT FIERCE. Nickel dragons are exceptionally small, possibly the smallest, species of true dragon. They make up for this lack of physical size with an unmatched tenacity in combat that makes them both highly aggressive and unpredictable. This attitude often extends beyond battle and into every aspect of a nickel dragon's life. Their small stature does often lead other creatures to assume they are younger than they actually are, a mistake which is often lethal.

TURNCOATS. Nickel dragons are naturally quite chaotic beings, however, seeing the way the civil war between the various species of ferrous dragons was going, they decided to switch sides and join with the iron, chromium, cobalt, and tungsten dragons. Upon doing so, they were subjected to the rigid structure of command employed by their new allies and over time these chaotic creatures grew to be more lawful in manners of conduct. Their roots as unbridled hooligans still show themselves once and awhile, but never when it is related to a matter of consequence.

DISREGARDED. As the weakest and lowest ranking members of the ferrous dragon hierarchy, nickel dragons are often left to their own devices. Not much is expected from them by their ferrous brethren, and as such they are free to chase whatever aims they please so long as they don't interfere with the plans of the other dragons they are beholden to.
NICKEL DRAGON LAIRS

Nickel dragons make their home in swamps and marshlands, preferring to be on or near the coast if possible. They typically occupy caves that contain water, but only as a place to store treasure and lay eggs. The dragon itself often lives in any place it finds suitable near the cave itself. This often changes from day to day, making their exact whereabouts less predictable than most other draconic creatures. Nickel dragon lairs often include the following features;
Various sub-lairs all hidden well around the primary lair.
Various chambers that are connected by underwater passageways.
Acidic bodies of water that deteriorate anyone or anything not immune to acid.
NICKEL DRAGON WYRMLINGS

As a wyrmling, nickel dragons are especially aware of their smaller size. Sometimes mistaken for large pseudodragons due to their lacking stature, this is a mistake they are quick to correct, usually with violence.

trait.name: Amphibious
entries: The nickel dragon wyrmling can breathe air and water.

trait.name: Flyby
entries: The nickel dragon wyrmling doesn't provoke opportunity attacks when it flies out of an enemy's reach.

trait.name: Legendary Resistance (1/Day in Lair)
entries: If the dragon fails a saving throw, it can choose to succeed instead.

trait.name: Surprise Attack
entries: If the dragon surprises a creature and hits it with an attack during the first round of combat, the target takes an extra 10 ({@damage 3d6}) damage from the attack.

action.name: Rend
entries: {@atkr m} {@hit 5} to hit, reach 5 ft. {@h}6 ({@dice 1d6 + 3}) Slashing plus 3 ({@damage 1d6}) Acid damage.

action.name: Acidic Breath {@recharge 5}
entries: {@actSave dex} {@dc 13}, each creature in a 15-foot Cone. {@actSaveFail} 22 ({@damage 5d8}) Acid damage. {@actSaveSuccess} Half damage.

spellcasting.name: Spellcasting
headerEntries: The dragon casts one of the following spells, requiring no material components, using Charisma as the spellcasting ability (spell save {@dc 13}).

bonus.name: Aggressive Advance
entries: The dragon moves up to its speed toward a hostile creature it can see.

bonus.name: Rampage
entries: When the dragon reduces a creature to 0 hit points with a melee attack on its turn, the dragon moves up to half its speed and makes a rend attack.

reaction.name: Backlash
entries: {@actTrigger} The dragon uses its Legendary Resistance Trait, or is hit with a ranged attack. {@actResponse} The dragon moves up to half its speed towards the creature who targeted it and makes a rend attack if able.

reaction.name: Misdirect
entries: {@actTrigger} The dragon is targeted by an attack roll. {@actResponse} The creature making the attack has disadvantage. If the attack misses, the dragon can move up to half its speed. If the attack hits the dragon has advantage on the next attack roll it makes against the creature it attempted to misdirect.

reaction.name: Rend Retaliation
entries: {@actTrigger} The dragon takes damage. {@actResponse} The dragon makes a Rend attack.

Nickel dragons are naturally quite chaotic beings, however, seeing the way the civil war between the various species of ferrous dragons was going, they decided to switch sides and join with the iron, chromium, cobalt, and tungsten dragons. Upon doing so, they were subjected to the rigid structure of command employed by their new allies and over time these chaotic creatures grew to be more lawful in manners of conduct. Their roots as unbridled hooligans still show themselves once and awhile, but never when it is related to a matter of consequence.

DISREGARDED. As the weakest and lowest ranking members of the ferrous dragon hierarchy, nickel dragons are often left to their own devices. Not much is expected from them by their ferrous brethren, and as such they are free to chase whatever aims they please so long as they don't interfere with the plans of the other dragons they are beholden to.
NICKEL DRAGON LAIRS

Nickel dragons make their home in swamps and marshlands, preferring to be on or near the coast if possible. They typically occupy caves that contain water, but only as a place to store treasure and lay eggs. The dragon itself often lives in any place it finds suitable near the cave itself. This often changes from day to day, making their exact whereabouts less predictable than most other draconic creatures. Nickel dragon lairs often include the following features;
Various sub-lairs all hidden well around the primary lair.
Various chambers that are connected by underwater passageways.
Acidic bodies of water that deteriorate anyone or anything not immune to acid.
YOUNG NICKEL DRAGON

Entering their second phase of life, nickel dragons finally begin to gain a sense of confidence about themselves, having learned to use their small size as an asset rather than a shortcoming. These dragons are particularly dangerous, as they will often lure in unsuspecting enemies who assume they are simply wyrmlings, only to quickly find out they are profoundly mistaken.

trait.name: Amphibious
entries: The nickel dragon wyrmling can breathe air and water.

trait.name: Flyby
entries: The nickel dragon wyrmling doesn't provoke opportunity attacks when it flies out of an enemy's reach.

trait.name: Legendary Resistance (2/Day in Lair)
entries: If the dragon fails a saving throw, it can choose to succeed instead.

trait.name: Surprise Attack
entries: If the dragon surprises a creature and hits it with an attack during the first round of combat, the target takes an extra 17 ({@damage 5d6}) damage from the attack.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The dragon makes three rend attacks.  It can replace one of these attacks with a use of Spellcasting (at will spells only).

action.name: Rend
entries: {@atkr m} {@hit 5} to hit, reach 5 ft. {@h}6 ({@dice 1d6 + 3}) Slashing plus 3 ({@damage 1d6}) Acid damage.

action.name: Acidic Breath {@recharge 5}
entries: {@actSave dex} {@dc 15}, each creature in a 30-foot Cone. {@actSaveFail} 45 ({@damage 10d8}) Acid damage. {@actSaveSuccess} Half damage.

spellcasting.name: Spellcasting
headerEntries: The dragon casts one of the following spells, requiring no material components, using Charisma as the spellcasting ability (spell save {@dc 15})

bonus.name: Aggressive Advance
entries: The dragon moves up to its speed toward a hostile creature it can see.

bonus.name: Rampage
entries: When the dragon reduces a creature to 0 hit points with a melee attack on its turn, the dragon moves up to half its speed and makes a rend attack.

reaction.name: Backlash
entries: {@actTrigger} The dragon uses its Legendary Resistance Trait, or is hit with a ranged attack. {@actResponse} The dragon moves up to half its speed towards the creature who targeted it and makes a rend attack if able.

reaction.name: Misdirect
entries: {@actTrigger} The dragon is targeted by an attack roll. {@actResponse} The creature making the attack has disadvantage. If the attack misses, the dragon can move up to half its speed. If the attack hits the dragon has advantage on the next attack roll it makes against the creature it attempted to misdirect.

reaction.name: Rend Retaliation
entries: {@actTrigger} The dragon takes damage. {@actResponse} The dragon makes a Rend attack.

The dragon before you has soft grey metallic scales that catch the sunlight in such a way as to suggest a precious metal. Their two horns jut out, slightly curved as if swept back, but still long and imposing. Despite the dragon's small size, it has a look of malice and rage within its eyes.

SMALL BUT FIERCE. Nickel dragons are exceptionally small, possibly the smallest, species of true dragon. They make up for this lack of physical size with an unmatched tenacity in combat that makes them both highly aggressive and unpredictable. This attitude often extends beyond battle and into every aspect of a nickel dragon's life. Their small stature does often lead other creatures to assume they are younger than they actually are, a mistake which is often lethal.

TURNCOATS. Nickel dragons are naturally quite chaotic beings, however, seeing the way the civil war between the various species of ferrous dragons was going, they decided to switch sides and join with the iron, chromium, cobalt, and tungsten dragons. Upon doing so, they were subjected to the rigid structure of command employed by their new allies and over time these chaotic creatures grew to be more lawful in manners of conduct. Their roots as unbridled hooligans still show themselves once and awhile, but never when it is related to a matter of consequence.

DISREGARDED. As the weakest and lowest ranking members of the ferrous dragon hierarchy, nickel dragons are often left to their own devices. Not much is expected from them by their ferrous brethren, and as such they are free to chase whatever aims they please so long as they don't interfere with the plans of the other dragons they are beholden to.
NICKEL DRAGON LAIRS

This often changes from day to day, making their exact whereabouts less predictable than most other draconic creatures. Nickel dragon lairs often include the following features;
Various sub-lairs all hidden well around the primary lair.
Various chambers that are connected by underwater passageways.
Acidic bodies of water that deteriorate anyone or anything not immune to acid.
ADULT NICKEL DRAGON

By the time a nickel dragon becomes an adult, they have learned how to expertly navigate the world and their surroundings with finesse and trickery. They may begin to grow more ambitious, turning to grander schemes that will elevate their territory and influence.

A long, conical, wormlike creature sails through the air. It's four gangly limbs each end in clawed hands with four digits. At the largest end of its body is a circular mouth housing countless razor-sharp teeth. At the tip of its tail is a stinger dripping with venom.

ANCIENT MAGICIANS. Phaerimm are exceptionally talented in the ways of the arcane, and can often live hundreds of years. This affords them a long life which is typically spent studying and enhancing their innate understanding of magic and its many mysteries. For this reason, phaerimm elders are exceptionally dangerous.

HIGH STANDARDS. Phaerimm can be very dangerous in physical combat, but they view using anything other than magic to do battle as a sign of intellectual weakness. They see the use of their natural attacks as an admission that their magical prowess was not enough to defend themselves, and as such, will only ever resort to physical attacks if they have no other option. Some young phaerimm may stoop to using enchanted weaponry while they are still learning the finer points of spellcasting.

CHARMING CREATURES. As spellcasters, the phaerimm favour using illusion and enchantment magic to defend themselves, often bringing an accompaniment of charmed creatures with them wherever they go to use as guardians. To a phaerimm, any encounter with another creature is little more than a chance to dominate them with magic and add the creature to its collection of toys.
ACCURSED EGGS

Phaerimms reproduce by implanting an egg into a living creature. They do this by piercing the target with their stinging tail and injecting the egg into their body. If a phaerimm is ready to reproduce, anytime it hits a living creature with its tail attack and the target fails their save by 5 or more, the target is infected with a parasitic pharimm egg. If the egg is not removed by magic that can cure diseases, after 5d6 days the egg inside the creature will hatch and the newborn phaerimm will devour the
creature from the inside, killing them instantly.

spellcasting.name: Spellcasting
headerEntries: The creature's innate spellcasting ability is Charisma (spell save {@dc 19}, +9 to hit with spell attacks). It can innately cast the following spells, requiring no material components:

trait.name: Immutable Form
entries: The phaerimm is immune to any spell or effect that would alter its form.

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: The phaerimm has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

trait.name: Magic Sense
entries: The phaerimm can detect any magic object or spell present within 300 feet of itself at any time. It knows the precise location of the object or spell and what school of magic (if any) resonates from the object or spell. It also knows if a creature it can see is capable of casting spells.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The phaerimm attacks twice with its claws, once with its bite, and once with its tail.

action.name: Claw
entries: {@atkr m} {@hit 9} to hit, reach 5 ft. {@h}12 ({@damage 2d6 + 5}) Slashing damage.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atkr m} {@hit 9} to hit, reach 5 ft. {@h}14 ({@damage 2d8 + 5}) Piercing damage and if the target has any unexpended spell slots, they must succeed on a {@dc 16} Intelligence Saving Throw or have a spell slot of the lowest level available to them expended and the phaerimm gains {@dice 1d12} temporary hit points per level of spell slot expended.

action.name: Tail
entries: {@atkr m} {@hit 9} to hit, reach 5 ft. {@h}9 ({@damage 1d8 + 5}) Piercing damage and 14 ({@damage 4d6}) poison damage, or half as much on a successful {@dc 16} Constitution Saving Throw. A creature who fails this save by 5 or more is {@condition paralyzed} for {@dice 2d4} rounds. While {@condition paralyzed} in this way the creature levitates 5 feet off the ground.

action.name: Phaerimm Domination {@recharge 5}
entries: The phaerimm attempts to dominate the will of a creature it can see within 120 feet. The target must succeed on a {@dc 19} Wisdom Saving Throw or be {@condition charmed} by the phaerimm for 24 hours. While the target is {@condition charmed} it has a telepathic link with the phaerimm, and it must do its best to obey any commands given by the phaerimm. If not given any directive, the creature is free to behave normally, though it will still be under the influence of the phaerimm and may have its general goals or personality tweaked to fall in line with the phaerimm's wishes.
The phaerimm can also take total and precise control of the creature, choosing its every action, however, this requires the phaerimm to expend its own action to do so.
Each time the target takes damage it is allowed a new Wisdom Saving Throw, ending the effect on a success.

The phaerimm's domination magic is so powerful that it can affect creatures who are immune to the {@condition charmed} condition, though such creatures do get advantage on their saving throw to resist.

bonus.name: Cast a Spell
entries: The phaerimm casts one of its at will spells.

bonus.name: Flurry of Claws
entries: The phaerimm makes two claw attacks.

reaction.name: Arcane Malformation
entries: {@actTrigger} A creature the phaerimm can see within 60 feet casts a spell. {@actResponse} The creature must succeed on a {@dc 19} Intelligence Saving Throw or take force damage equal to {@dice 1d8}  for each level of the spell they are casting.

A massive head, once belonging to a towering giant, brought low and infused with necrotic magic. An unsightly mess of organs and meaty tendrils sprout from the creature's neck, propelling the undead terror forward on its gruesome path.

PRIDE'S REWARD. The crawling head is an abomination that spits in the face of all that is good in the world. The first of these horrific creatures was created by an overzealous necromancer who was dabbling in magic he did not have the means to control. He successfully animated the severed giant head, hoping to use it as a conduit to the realm of the dead. Instead, the creature killed him, and his severed head became the first of many that would know the true horror of being trapped within his creation. Since then, other crawling heads have cropped up in regions where giants are frequently present, suggesting that they are somehow propagating.

FOUL SAGES. Unlike most undead creatures, crawling heads are very intelligent, and they have a mind of their own. They enjoy collecting knowledge by severing the heads of mortal creatures and slowly picking their way through all the knowledge possessed by them. By combining spells like speak with dead and detect thoughts, they are able to slowly absorb everything a creature knew in life. They are greedy when it comes to the acquisition of knowledge and rarely give up their secrets unless coerced or offered something worth their while.

trait.name: Cacophony
entries: When the crawling head makes an attack roll, if it has at least 10 heads stored in its body, all creatures within 60 feet of it that can hear must succeed on a {@dc 18} Wisdom Saving Throw or be {@condition Frightened|XPHB} of the crawling head until the start of its next turn.

trait.name: Cranium Collector
entries: A crawling head can store up to 30 severed heads inside its body at once. When it absorbs a head to fuel one of its abilities, the head is utterly destroyed. A crawling head typically has {@dice 1d6 + 8} heads stored in its body.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The crawling head makes an attack with its vorpal bite, and two attacks with its tendrils.

action.name: Vorpal Bite
entries: {@atkr m} {@hit 14} to hit, reach 5 ft. {@h}24 ({@damage 3d10 + 8}) Slashing damage. On a roll of 19 or 2o this attack is a critical hit. On a critical hit, if the target is large or smaller, the target's head is severed from its body. The creature dies if it can't survive without the lost head. The severed head is then stored inside the crawling head's body. A creature is immune to this effect if it is immune to slashing damage, or it doesn't have or need a head.

action.name: Tendrils
entries: {@atkr m} {@hit 14} to hit, reach 15 ft. {@h}17 ({@damage 2d8 + 8}) Bludgeoning damage and the target is {@condition Grappled|XPHB} (escape {@dc 18}).

spellcasting.name: Spellcasting
headerEntries: The crawling head's innate spellcasting ability is Charisma (spell save {@dc 20}, +12 to hit with spell attacks). It can innately cast the following spells, requiring no material components:

bonus.name: Gruesome Quicken
entries: The crawling head absorbs one of the heads it has stored in its body. It then casts a spell with a casting time of one action.

reaction.name: Psychic Backlash
entries: {@actTrigger} A creature tries to read the crawling head's thoughts. {@actResponse} The crawling head unleashes a cacophony of psychic screams in the mind of the creature dealing {@damage 1d6} psychic damage per head stored in its body.

legendary.name: Constrict
entries: The crawling head deals 7 ({@damage 2d6}) bludgeoning damage to a creature {@condition grappled} by it.

legendary.name: Regenerate
entries: The crawling head absorbs one of the heads stored in its body and regains 13 ({@dice 3d8}) Hit Points.

spellcasting.name: Spellcasting
headerEntries: The phoenix's innate spell casting ability is Charisma (spell save {@dc 18}). It can innately cast the following spells, requiring no material components:

trait.name: Keen Sight
entries: The phoenix has advantage on Wisdom (Perception) checks that rely on sight

trait.name: Shriek of the Phoenix
entries: When the phoenix first enters combat, as a free action, it lets loose a piercing shriek that can be heard for miles.  All creatures within 260 ft. of the phoenix are {@condition deafened} for 1 minute and any creatures that can hear within 6 miles must make a {@dc 18} Wisdom save, or be {@condition frightened} of the phoenix.

trait.name: Aura of Eternal Flame
entries: The phoenix sheds bright light in a 60 ft. radius, and dim light for another 120 ft. The phoenix can cause all creatures within 60 ft. to take 11 ({@damage 2d10}) fire damage at the start of each of its turns. ifs t does so, all creatures within 5 ft. suffer the effects of the {@spell heat metal} spell for 1 round. This light is considered natural sunlight. The phoenix also benefits from the effects of a {@spell detect evil and good} spell in the aura's affected area.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The phoenix makes two attacks: one with its break and on with its talons.

action.name: Beak
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 13} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target.
{@h}27 ({@damage 4d8 + 9}) piercing damage.

action.name: Talons
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 13} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target.

{@h}23 ({@damage 4d6 + 9}) slashing damage, and the target is {@condition grappled} (escape {@dc 19}). Until this grapple ends, the target is {@condition restrained}, and the phoenix can't use its talons on another target.

action.name: Radiant Fire Breath {@recharge 5}
entries: The phoenix exhales fire in a 60-foot cone. Each creature in that area must make a {@dc 21} Dexterity saving throw, taking 27 ({@damage 7d6}) fire damage and 27 ({@damage 7d6}) radiant damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

legendary.name: Instinct
entries: The phoenix can make a Wisdom (Insight) check with advantage.

legendary.name: Restore (Costs 2 Actions)
entries: The phoenix recovers 16 ({@dice 3d10}) hit points.

legendary.name: Flare (Costs 3 Actions)
entries: The phoenix flaps its wings and exudes a great wave of heat. All creatures within 120 ft. are knocked {@condition prone} and must make a {@dc 21} Dexterity saving throw, taking 27 ({@damage 7d6}) fire damage on a failed save, or half as much on a successful one.

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: The ashira has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

trait.name: Speak with Beasts and Plants
entries: The ashira can communicate with Beasts and Plants as if they shared a language.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The creature makes two Thorny Claw attacks or an attack with its Sticky Sap, and it can use Spellcasting to cast Charm Monster.

action.name: Thorny Claws
entries: {@atkr m} {@hit 6} to hit, reach 5 ft. {@h}7 ({@damage 1d6 + 4}) Piercing damage.

action.name: Sticky Sap
entries: {@atkr r} {@hit 6} to hit, range 60 ft. {@h}6 ({@damage 1d4 + 4}) Bludgeoning damage and the target is {@condition Restrained|XPHB} (escape {@dc 14}).

Ashira are tree spirits who reside in trees which grow in the desert. For this reason they are often referred to as dryads of the desert, however, they behave in ways much different from their woodland cousins. They live primarily in domesticated groves of date, coconut palm, orange, lemon, plum, fig, pomegranate, and banana trees.

An ashira consumes sunlight during the day, and processes that energy at night. This nightly processing of energy gives off a faint glow that can be seen from miles away when there are no other sources of light. This has led to many tall tales about the groves inhabited by these fey creatures. Many locals who are unfamiliar with the ashira believe these places are haunted and the faint lights seen from the distance is created by unruly spirits.

Ashira, unlike dryads, are not beholden to a single tree. Instead, they are tied inexorably to the entire orchard of trees which they call home. Often these trees are tended to by other creatures who the ashira regale with song and dance as they take care of the trees in which they live. Ashira are incredibly friendly and enjoy the company of other ashira as well as any other creatures with whom they can converse and laugh. When the orchard is threatened, any ashira who live there act in unison to dismiss the threat, always preferring to knock an opposing creature unconscious and release them far from the grove over killing them.  They are able to move freely through their home with incredible speed thanks to the magic that binds them with the grove as a community. This communal nature goes beyond a mere preference for an ashira. If forced to live alone for some reason, they will become despondent and moody, seeking out connection with any creatures they can and trying to convince them to stay in their grove.

spellcasting.name: Spellcasting
headerEntries: The ashira casts one of the following spells, requiring no Material components and using Charisma as the spellcasting ability (spell save {@dc 14}):
will: {@spell charm monster|XPHB} (lasts 24 hours; ends early if the ashira casts the spell again)

bonus.name: Tree Stride
entries: If within 5 feet of a Large or bigger tree, the ashira teleports to an unoccupied space within 5 feet of a second Large or bigger tree that is within 120 feet of the previous tree.

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: The ashira has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

trait.name: Speak with Beasts and Plants
entries: The ashira can communicate with Beasts and Plants as if they shared a language.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The creature makes two Thorny Claw attacks or an attack with its Sticky Sap, and it can use Spellcasting to cast Charm Monster.

action.name: Siphoning Claws
entries: {@atkr m} {@hit 7} to hit, reach 5 ft. {@h}7 ({@damage 1d6 + 4}) Piercing damage and 7 ({@damage 2d6}) Necrotic damage. The ashira restores a number of Hit Points equal to half the Necrotic damage dealt.

action.name: Sticky Sap
entries: {@atkr r} {@hit 7} to hit, range 60 ft. {@h}6 ({@damage 1d4 + 4}) Bludgeoning damage and the target is {@condition Restrained|XPHB} (escape {@dc 15}).

action.name: Quench Thirst (1/Day)
entries: {@actSave con} {@dc 15}, each creature of the ashira's choice within 60 feet that isn't a Construct or Undead. Plants and water Elementals have Disadvantage. {@actSaveFail} 54 ({@damage 12d8}) Necrotic damage. {@actSaveSuccess} Half damage. {@actSaveSuccessOrFail} A creature reduced to 0 Hit Points dies instantly and their body becomes a desiccated husk. For each creature killed, the ashira can immediately cast the Awaken spell on a non-magical tree it can see within 120 feet.

Ashira are tree spirits who reside in trees which grow in the desert. For this reason they are often referred to as dryads of the desert, however, they behave in ways much different from their woodland cousins. They live primarily in domesticated groves of date, coconut palm, orange, lemon, plum, fig, pomegranate, and banana trees.

Some tales tell of a crueler ashiran past, one where regular sacrifices were made to the fey creatures in exchange for fruit and other blessings. These stories talk of blood rites performed in order to feed the victim's life essence to the trees in the ashiran orchards. Whether these stories are true or not is unknown, though they do persist with unsettling regularity, and there are some ashira who have taken to extracting water from their victims rather than relying on other creatures to bring it to them.

spellcasting.name: Spellcasting
headerEntries: The ashira casts one of the following spells, requiring no Material components and using Charisma as the spellcasting ability (spell save {@dc 14}):
will: {@spell charm monster|XPHB} (lasts 24 hours; ends early if the ashira casts the spell again)

bonus.name: Tree Stride
entries: If within 5 feet of a Large or bigger tree, the ashira teleports to an unoccupied space within 5 feet of a second Large or bigger tree that is within 120 feet of the previous tree.

Adamantine dragon wyrmlings spend their earliest days learning about how to best defend themselves in combat, then are allowed to choose one magic item (typically a weapon) from their parent's hoard before venturing into the world to rescue those in need and put evil-doers to the sword. Most wyrmlings start out by taking down bandit gangs and other relatively mundane threats to the innocent before graduating to tougher foes.

entries.name: Adamantine Dragons
entries: {@i Peerless Defenders of Justice}

items.entry: Planar (Bytopia), {@filter Urban|bestiary|environment=urban}

entries: Adamantine dragons hail from the celestial plane of Bytopia, a twin world of pristine and enigmatic beauty. They pride themselves on being protectors of those who can't protect themselves, and will quickly intervene with any means necessary to thwart those who would see harm come to innocents. Using both their white hot flames and ability to influence other creature's perception of time, they fearlessly defend the multiverse against evildoers and their minions.

Adamantine dragons live in fortified locations that they construct alongside the creatures they have dedicated themselves to protecting. For a young dragon, this might mean taking up residence in a fortified keep that can act as the last line of defense against invasion from an outside force. For an ancient adamantine dragon, this could be a grand citadel, meticulously constructed over many years to act as a central bulwark for all people who occupy the lands surrounding it. They tend to hoard magical weapons, armor, and other implements of warfare so that they may outfit their allies with equipment to aid them in their defense against the dark forces of the world.

entries.name: Adamantine Dragon Lairs
entries: Adamantine dragons make their homes in hallowed halls and grand keeps constructed by them and their allies.

trait.name: Adamantine Scales
entries: Any Critical Hit against the dragon becomes a normal hit.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The dragon makes two Rend attacks.

action.name: Rend
entries: {@atkr m} {@hit 7} to hit, reach 5 ft. {@h}11 ({@damage 1d10 + 5}) Slashing damage plus 6 ({@damage 1d10}) Fire damage. This damage bypasses resistance to Fire but not immunity. If the target is an object, a normal hit with this attack becomes a Critical Hit.

action.name: Fire Breath {@recharge 5}
entries: {@actSave dex} {@dc 14}, each creature in either a 15-foot Cone or 30-foot Line. {@actSaveFail} 32 ({@damage 5d12}) Fire damage. {@actSaveSuccess} Half damage. This damage bypasses resistance to Fire but not immunity.

action.name: Slowing Breath (1/Day)
entries: {@actSave wis} {@dc 14}, each creature in a 15-foot Cone. {@actSaveFail} The creature is {@condition paralyzed} for 1 minute. {@actSaveSuccess} The creature is slowed for 1 minute, imposing  a −2 penalty to AC and Dexterity saving throws, and it can't take Reactions. A creature can make a save at the end of each of its turns to become slowed if they are {@condition paralyzed} , or to end the effect on themselves if they are slowed.

Young adamantine dragons have gained plenty of experience dealing with the forces of evil and have learned the lessons of combat well. They often seek out strong allies to aid them in their never ending crusade against those that would see innocents come to harm.

entries.name: Adamantine Dragons
entries: {@i Peerless Defenders of Justice}

monster.name: Adult Adamantine Dragon

entries: Adult adamantine dragons often find themselves fulfilling the role of a master tactician or seasoned general in grand conflicts against villainous forces that demand their attention. While they are happy to take the lead when it comes to organizing their allies, they are also always the first to jump directly into battle, relishing the opportunity to cast down the wicked.

entries.name: Adamantine Dragons
entries: {@i Peerless Defenders of Justice}

entries.name: Adamantine Dragon Lairs
entries: Adamantine dragons make their homes in hallowed halls and grand keeps constructed by them and their allies.
The region containing an adult or ancient adamantine dragon's lair is altered by its presence, creating the following effects:

items.name: Bonded Guardianship
entries: While in its lair, the dragon can cast {@spell Warding Bond}, requiring no Material components, targeting up to 6 creatures that are within 1 mile of its lair. It does not need to make physical contact with these creatures or be able to see them. The spell functions as long as the creatures remain within 1 mile of the dragon's lair.

items.name: Hallowed Grounds
entries: The area within 1 mile of the lair is under the effects of a {@spell Hallow} spell, and dead bodies interred in the area can't be turned into undead. The creature type affected by the spell is chosen by the dragon each day at dawn.
If the dragon dies or moves its lair elsewhere, these effects end immediately.

trait.name: Adamantine Scales
entries: Any Critical Hit against the dragon becomes a normal hit.

trait.name: Legendary Resistance (3/Day, or 4/Day in Lair)
entries: If the dragon fails a saving throw, it can choose to succeed instead.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The dragon makes three Rend attacks. It can replace one attack with a use of (A) Spellcasting to cast {@spell Dispel Magic} (B) Either of its breath weapons.

action.name: Rend
entries: {@atkr m} {@hit 11} to hit, reach 10 ft. {@h}18 ({@damage 2d10 + 7}) Slashing damage plus 7 ({@damage 1d12}) Fire damage. This damage bypasses resistance to Fire but not immunity. If the target is an object, a normal hit with this attack becomes a Critical Hit.

action.name: Fire Breath {@recharge 5}
entries: {@atkr m} {@hit 15} to hit, reach 10 ft. {@h}20 ({@damage 2d10 + 9}) Slashing damage plus 7 ({@damage 1d12}) Fire damage. This damage bypasses resistance to Fire but not immunity. If the target is an object, a normal hit with this attack becomes a Critical Hit.

action.name: Slowing Breath (1/Day)
entries: {@actSave wis} {@dc 22}, each creature in a 60-foot Cone. {@actSaveFail} The creature is {@condition paralyzed} for 1 minute. {@actSaveSuccess} The creature is slowed for 1 minute, imposing  a −2 penalty to AC and Dexterity saving throws, and it can't take Reactions. A creature can make a save at the end of each of its turns to become slowed if they are {@condition paralyzed} , or to end the effect on themselves if they are slowed.

spellcasting.name: Spellcasting
headerEntries: The dragon innately casts one of the following spells, requiring no material components and using Wisdom as the spellcasting ability (spell save {@dc 21}):
will: {@spell shapechange|XPHB} (Beast or Humanoid form only, no Temporary Hit Points gained from the spell, and no Concentration or Temporary Hit Points required to maintain the spell)

legendaryHeader: Legendary Action Uses: 3 (4 in Lair). Immediately after another creature's turn, the dragon can expend a use to take one of the following actions. The dragon regains all expended uses at the start of each of its turns.

legendary.name: Fearsome Stomp
entries: {@actSave dex} {@dc 22}, all creatures within 15 feet of the dragon. {@actSaveFail} The target is {@condition Prone|XPHB} and becomes {@condition Frightened|XPHB} of the dragon until the end of its next turn. {@actSaveSuccessOrFail} The dragon can't take this action again until the start of its next turn.

legendary.name: Protect
entries: The dragon moves up to half its Speed, and it protects any number of creatures within 10 feet of it, giving them a +2 bonus to their AC as long as they remain within 10 feet of the dragon until the start of the dragon's next turn.

legendary.name: Retribution
entries: The dragon makes a rend attack and casts Divine Smite.

monster.name: Ancient Adamantine Dragon

entries: Ancient adamantine dragons are extremely rare. Many of their kind perish while executing a selfless act defending those who they swore to protect. A fortunate few live through countless battles to witness ages pass by. Such individuals are extremely powerful, and horrifically dangerous to those they oppose. Very few creatures in the multiverse can stand against the all-consuming tempest of an adamantine dragon's peak combat prowess coupled with a mind that has been sharpened to a perfect tactical edge. They are truly a boon like no other to the creatures they defend, and a promise of destruction to their enemies.

entries.name: Adamantine Dragons
entries: {@i Peerless Defenders of Justice}

A wizard's shackle is an intelligent, eel-like parasite covered in sensory flanges that glow in an impressive array of colours. They are typically quite animalistic, acting purely on instinct and stimuli around them, however, once they detect a creature capable of casting spells, the creatures become extremely aggressive. They will rush towards creatures who house magic potential with the goal of latching on to them and taking control of the host's body. Once in control of a dominated host, the true potential of the parasite's intelligence is revealed.

Driven by bizarre and near incomprehensible motivations, a wizard's shackle in control of a spellcaster's body will immediately set out to take on a wide variety of tasks. These tasks are typically benign, but strange, such as using magic to steal all the silverware from a noble's manse, or making repairs to a stranger's roof. It is rare for the parasite to force its host into acts of brutality or murder, though when this does happen often the dominated individual was predisposed to such things in the first place which suggests there is something more than mere domination of will at play.

MANA GEMS - When a wizard's shackle has absorbed enough mana from a creature it is latched on to, it will produce a hard, gemstone-like object at the end of its tail. This object is actually an egg, which will detach from the creature after 1d4 days. If left undisturbed and submerged in water, the egg will hatch into 3d4 wizard's shackles. Before the egg hatches, as a bonus action, a creature can crush the egg in order to restore a level 1 spell slot.

A wizard's shackle attached to a host has an almost childlike curiosity about the world. They become obsessed with exploring the world and only the allure of gaining more knowledge and new experiences can distract them from their bizarre tasks. Occasionally, they will form social groups with other wizard's shackles that have managed to dominate a host. These collectives often work towards even more esoteric and ambitious goals such as constructing odd structures that serve no obvious purpose.

trait.name: Arcane Sense
entries: The wizard's shackle can sense magic objects, spell effects, and creatures that have spell slots, within 120 feet.

trait.name: Host Buffer
entries: A wizard's shackle that has {@condition charmed} another creature uses that creature's Saving Throws if they are better.

trait.name: Puppet Master
entries: While the wizard's shackle is attached to a creature {@condition charmed} by it, it has a telepathic link with the creature. The wizard's shackle can use its action to take total and precise control of the target. Until the end of its next turn, the creature takes only actions chosen by the wizard's shackle, and doesn't do anything it doesn't allow it to do. During this time it can also use its reaction to cause the creature to use a reaction.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit -1} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}-1 ({@damage 1d4 - 3}) piercing damage. The target's Wisdom score is reduced by 2 ({@dice 1d4}), and the wizard's shackle attaches to the target. The wizard's shackle can detach itself by spending 5 feet of its movement. The target or a creature within 5 feet of it can attempt to detach the wizard's shackle by making a {@dc 16} Strength (Athletics) check.

action.name: Absorb Magic
entries: {@actSave wis} {@dc 13}, one creature with spell slots that the wizard's shackle is attached to. {@actSaveFail} The wizard's shackle absorbs a spell slot at the lowest level available to a creature it is grappling. This expends the spell slot as if it had been used to cast a spell, and grants the wizard's shackle {@dice 1d8} temporary Hit Points per level of the spell absorbed.

bonus.name: Dominate Mage
entries: {@actSave wis} {@dc 13}, one creature with spell slots the wizard's shackle is attached to. {@actSaveFail} The creature is {@condition charmed} by the wizard's shackle for as long as it is attached to the target.

A wizard's shackle is an intelligent, eel-like parasite covered in sensory flanges that glow in an impressive array of colours. They are typically quite animalistic, acting purely on instinct and stimuli around them, however, once they detect a creature capable of casting spells, the creatures become extremely aggressive. They will rush towards creatures who house magic potential with the goal of latching on to them and taking control of the host's body. Once in control of a dominated host, the true potential of the parasite's intelligence is revealed.

Driven by bizarre and near incomprehensible motivations, a wizard's shackle in control of a spellcaster's body will immediately set out to take on a wide variety of tasks. These tasks are typically benign, but strange, such as using magic to steal all the silverware from a noble's manse, or making repairs to a stranger's roof. It is rare for the parasite to force its host into acts of brutality or murder, though when this does happen often the dominated individual was predisposed to such things in the first place which suggests there is something more than mere domination of will at play.

MANA GEMS - When a wizard's shackle has absorbed enough mana from a creature it is latched on to, it will produce a hard, gemstone-like object at the end of its tail. This object is actually an egg, which will detach from the creature after 1d4 days. If left undisturbed and submerged in water, the egg will hatch into 3d4 wizard's shackles. Before the egg hatches, as a bonus action, a creature can crush the egg in order to restore a level 1 spell slot.

When a large population of wizard's shackles gather in whatever body of water they reside in, they can sometimes be riled into a frenzy at the presence of magic or a creature capable of casting magic. They will roil and writhe atop one another in an attempt to be the first to latch on to whatever creature has found its way into their lair.

trait.name: Arcane Sense
entries: The wizard's shackle can sense magic objects, spell effects, and creatures that have spell slots, within 120 feet.

trait.name: Swarm
entries: The swarm can occupy another creature's space and vice versa, and the swarm can move though any opening large enough for a Tiny creature. The swarm can't regain Hit Points or gain Temporary Hit Points.

action.name: Swarm of Bites
entries: {@atkr m} {@hit 4} to hit, reach 5 ft. {@h}6 ({@damage 2d8 - 3}) Piercing damage and the target's Wisdom score is reduced by 5 ({@dice 2d4}), or 2 ({@damage 1d8 - 3}) Piercing damage and the target's Wisdom score is reduced by 2 ({@dice 1d4}) if the swarm is Bloodied. If there is a medium or smaller creature in the swarm's space, the target has the {@condition Grappled|XPHB} condition (Escape {@dc 16}).

action.name: Absorb Magic
entries: {@actSave wis} {@dc 13}, one creature with spell slots that is being {@condition grappled} by the swarm. {@actSaveFail} The swarm absorbs {@dice 1d4} spell slots at the lowest level available to a creature {@condition grappled} by it. This expends the spell slots as if they had been used to cast a spell.

bonus.name: Dominate Mage
entries: {@actSave wis} {@dc 13}, made with disadvantage, one creature with spell slots that is being {@condition grappled} by the wizard's shackle. {@actSaveFail} The swarm takes 1 damage and a single wizard's shackle appears in the same space as the swarm, attached to the creature being {@condition grappled} by the swarm. The creature is {@condition charmed} by the newly created wizard's shackle for as long as it is attached to the target.

A wizard's shackle is an intelligent, eel-like parasite covered in sensory flanges that glow in an impressive array of colours. They are typically quite animalistic, acting purely on instinct and stimuli around them, however, once they detect a creature capable of casting spells, the creatures become extremely aggressive. They will rush towards creatures who house magic potential with the goal of latching on to them and taking control of the host's body. Once in control of a dominated host, the true potential of the parasite's intelligence is revealed.

Driven by bizarre and near incomprehensible motivations, a wizard's shackle in control of a spellcaster's body will immediately set out to take on a wide variety of tasks. These tasks are typically benign, but strange, such as using magic to steal all the silverware from a noble's manse, or making repairs to a stranger's roof. It is rare for the parasite to force its host into acts of brutality or murder, though when this does happen often the dominated individual was predisposed to such things in the first place which suggests there is something more than mere domination of will at play.

MANA GEMS - When a wizard's shackle has absorbed enough mana from a creature it is latched on to, it will produce a hard, gemstone-like object at the end of its tail. This object is actually an egg, which will detach from the creature after 1d4 days. If left undisturbed and submerged in water, the egg will hatch into 3d4 wizard's shackles. Before the egg hatches, as a bonus action, a creature can crush the egg in order to restore a level 1 spell slot.

On rare occasions, a wizard's shackle may possess a host for long enough to learn about the world in such a profound way that its intelligence grows beyond the need for a host. The creature surely still benefits from being attached to a spellcaster of course, but it is able to retain its intelligence and sense of self even when detached from a host's body. These creatures are often much less dangerous than a typical wizard's shackle as they have more understanding about what it is they are doing when they enslave another creature's mind, and as such, often choose to abstain from dominating others. Many even learn to work together with a host rather than assuming full control, sometimes even studying the arcane arts to develop their own spellcasting abilities. An evil archwizard shackle is, however, a tremendous threat to all who reside within its territory. Some of the most heinous acts committed by spellcasters are said to be attributed to the influence of an archwizard's shackle that has chosen a path of darkness.

entries: The wizard's shackle can sense magic objects, spell effects, and creatures that have spell slots, within 240 feet.

trait.name: Host Buffer
entries: A wizard's shackle that has {@condition charmed} another creature uses that creature's Saving Throws if they are better.

trait.name: Puppet Master
